webTitle: How FA got it half right

fields.headline: How FA got it half right
fields.standfirst: Right decision, wrong man as prime mover David Dein juggles Arsenal and England in selectorial role
fields.trailText: The recruitment of Eriksson smacks of right decision, wrong man.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson was 'always the No 1 choice' to be the new England head coach, the FA's chief executive, Adam Crozier, insisted. It seems curious then that within 24 hours of Kevin Keegan's resignation, Arsène Wenger was invited to take charge of the national team.

I understand that on the Sunday following England's 1-0 defeat by Germany, a senior figure at the FA was deputed to ask Wenger if he would take charge for the match in Finland in three days' time. The Arsenal manager politely declined, deeming the idea unworkable.

Since that day of panic, the FA appear not to have asked Wenger directly again if he would be interested in taking the job, probably as a result of his initial response. The subsequent recruitment of Eriksson, whom the FA have been at pains to point out resembles Wenger in calm, dignified bearing and enlightened outlook, smacks of right decision, wrong man.

'Let me just clear this once and for all,' said David Dein, vice-chairman at both Arsenal and the FA, at the end of two hours of talking to the media on the day Eriksson was paraded. 'Arsène has made it very clear that he believes his future is with Arsenal Football Club. Once we knew that Sir Alex Ferguson, Arsène Wenger and Gérard Houllier were going to be unavailable, it was a question then of compiling the shortlist.'

'This was all about the art of the possible,' Dein also said. 'There was no point wasting our energies on somebody we couldn't get.' It was clear from Dein's very presence at Eriksson's press conference that he had been a prime mover in the recruitment. He had, he said, known the Swede for nine years.

Crozier, who made it clear that Dein left discussions of the seven-man selection panel when his own manager's name cropped up, said that he believed there was 'no need to' talk to Wenger, given the Frenchman's public pronouncements. At the very least, it might have been interesting for the FA to have heard from a studious, expert figure his views on the English game after four years of success in it.

The chief executive's position is at odds with his recent statement that all the top managers would be consulted, at odds also with the FA's repeated stance that what managers say in public is not always what they say in private when approached about the job. 'I don't know why,' Wenger himself said last week, after confirming that the FA had not contacted him directly. It should also be pointed out that, at the time the FA were courting Eriksson, Wenger and Dein were discussing a new club contract for the Arsenal coach.

Ah, the inner workings, machinations and politics of the FA. Dein and Crozier may well be right. The best-looking girl in the class may well have declined to dance. But now we are left, like shy, regretful schoolboys, wondering for five years if just maybe.... As Eriksson said: 'When you get the opportunity, you can't say no.'

As with all matters relating to English football, it seems, it was a fishy business. The FA's selectorial seven decided on Eriksson at a meeting on Thursday 19 October, only their second, with Terry Venables having been ruled out for his lack of 'sustained success'. On the following morning, Eriksson - or Svenners, as he could become known - was backed down from around 25-1 to 6-4 favourite before certain bookmakers suspended betting in the afternoon. Wenger himself admits to having backed the Swede. How could that have happened? For once, Crozier had no answer.

A say-one-thing, do-another culture at the FA was seen one Friday morning a few weeks ago when Crozier said that they would talk to only two or three senior players about Keegan's successor. Later that day he volunteered to a tabloid newspaper the story that at least a dozen had been contacted.

Still, consulting the players appears to have been a fruitful exercise. For what emerged was a picture of Keegan's squad at Euro 2000 riven by cliques off the field, with several senior figures concerned about the effects of some serious gambling by certain players, the disaffection and disharmony off the pitch mirrored in some drained, disjointed and ill-planned performances on it. Of course, when it was written at the time, the FA denied it.

More important, the players felt almost to a man that while they received the best coaching at their clubs, it was not always true at England level. Indeed, there has been a tradition for too long of the manager bringing in cronies from his club past, rather than the best available.

It was significant that Erikkson stressed as his first task the need 'to create a good group, a good ambient in the side. If you don't have that feeling in your group you will never do good results. I never thought about 4-4-2 or 4-3-3 as the most important. Attitude is the most important'. He then spoke of attacking and defending as a group. 'That is rather easy.' Not for Keegan's England, it wasn't.

Part of the deal with Eriksson was that he would be allowed one man (like a condemned man with a meal, you almost stop yourself saying) and his trusted lieutenant, Tord Grip, will at first scout the English game for him. Eriksson is expected, though, to work with and develop a new generation of English coaches, among them Peter Taylor, Steve McClaren, Alan Curbishley and Brian Kidd. The likes of David Platt, Alan Shearer and Tony Adams may also be involved if and when they obtain Uefa coaching licences, the value of which the FA have belatedly come to recognise.

The aim is to prevent the English game falling again into the mess that has seen them finally - admirably - admit that they need help to regain ground ceded over the past two years. 'He'll have to understand the mentality of the English,' someone said on a phone-in last week. Actually, we islanders need to understand more the mentality of those who have taken the game to new levels.

It wouldn't happen in other major footballing nations, say some. Other? Results and world rankings are evidence that England are not one of them. How symbolic that latterly a nation's crumbling infrastructure, as payment for past neglect, has been reflected in its football team.

The game having moved on, it is not possible to develop coaches in-house the way the Germans did in the Seventies and Eighties, followed by the French in the Nineties, since club management these days is such an attractively lucrative alternative. The FA believe that bringing in the new breed for international weeks will not unduly interfere with their club commitments and also enable them to accumulate daily experience over the next five years; taking the best of the French system and adapting it to a nation of strong club football, as Aimé Jacquet advocated in these pages recently.

'There can't be a weak link,' says Crozier. 'Because the demands on the head coach are huge, those people who take the training sessions and work with players on an individual basis are very important. So they have to be the best people, otherwise the whole comes down.'

He adds that such a potentially large number of coaches is being considered for two main reasons. The first is that should one or more be unavailable, there are enough to cover. Second, it gives the FA a bigger and better pool of candidates when contemplating Eriksson's successor.

'If someone is the "chosen one", being groomed as the next England manager [as it was thought Bryan Robson was when he was a Venables assistant], it puts an incredible pressure on them and their club,' says Crozier. 'So if you spread that, as with Germany and France, when the point man moves on, one of that group is ready to step into the breach.'

It is also envisaged that the group of coaches will work with England's age-group teams to gain international experience. For the moment, the technical director, Howard Wilkinson, will remain in charge of the under-21's in Italy this month, but, says Crozier, 'he is looking at the structure and how to get the best out of it'.

They are all steps in the right direction. Crozier and co have been brave in ignoring arrogant, populist clamour to do the expedient thing, instead preferring the bold move of humbly accepting short-term help for long-term progress. In choosing Wenger for Arsenal, David Dein was proved right, after all, and Eriksson deserves the same fair crack of the whip. Wenger himself has said so; just a shame that he didn't fancy cracking it himself .

fields.headline: When France led the way
fields.trailText: It does work: in France three decades ago they invited a Romanian to come in and transform an international team in crisis.
fields.body:
Here's a familiar scenario: Foreign yet highly-respected club manager, with language skills and feel for local culture, agrees to rescue ailing footballing nation. It happened in France three decades ago when they invited a Romanian, Stefan Kovacs, to transform an international team in crisis.

Michel Hidalgo, his assistant and eventual successor, remembers it as an intriguing, important time in French football: 'There was a lack of confidence and we had to choose someone who had achieved great results. He was not seen as an enemy but someone who could help. It wasn't a case of people thinking he he was a foreigner who had taken a Frenchman's rightful place. Kovacs was the ideal man because he had great stature coming from Ajax, having taken them to the first of their European Cups but he was also a French speaker and someone who understood our mentality because Romania is the most Latin of Eastern European countries.

'Two things helped him enormously; because of his reputation he had the support of the club coaches - and you can't work in a country with all the major clubs against you - and he could communicate well in French. He created a good atmosphere and was an effective front man whilst behind the scenes others were working to create the youth development system which has been a hallmark of French football.'

Results-wise it was not the most successful era but Kovacs had served a crucial purpose. He had lifted spirits and done a lot of groundwork, and when Hidalgo took over France began to flourish. Under his guidance they reached the World Cup semi-final in 1982 and won the European Championship in 1984. Sven, Peter, Steve and co have a decent example to follow.

fields.headline: County game to face probe
fields.trailText: Sir Paul Condon has warned that his investigation into corruption in international cricket may be expanded to look into alleged match-fixing in the English domestic game.
fields.byline: Luke Harding  in New Delhi and Denis Campbell
fields.body:
Sir Paul Condon has warned that his investigation into corruption in international cricket may be expanded to look into alleged match-fixing in the English domestic game.

The former Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police said his team would scrutinise the performance of players under suspicion when they appeared in domestic games and not just international matches. 'Clearly if we are investigating an international player, we would be looking at his behaviour [generally]', Sir Paul told Observer Sport. 'There are no firewalls, no sheets of paper, between the international game and the domestic game. Our starting point is what has happened at international level [but] we will follow our leads wherever they take us.'

His remarks come amid growing fears that English county cricket may have been tainted by the same sort of scandal that has dragged the international game into the gutter. Many of the players implicated already in match-fixing had spells here.

Former Essex bowler Don Topley, who claims Essex and Lancashire 'fixed' two games between them at Old Trafford in 1991, welcomed Sir Paul's likely foray into domestic cricket. Topley alleges the two counties 'arranged' that Essex would win a Championship game in return for losing to Lancashire in a Sunday League match.

Essex won the Championship game and took the county title, while Lancashire prevailed in the Sunday League fixture but ended the season behind winners Nottinghamshire. Topley points to the involvement of players such as Salim Malik and Wasim Akram, now implicated in corruption.

'Of course the domestic game should be looked at for skulduggery surrounding match-fixing,' said Topley. 'I was the first person to suggest that skulduggery and match-fixing was going on and that there was a lot that the cricketing public were being hoodwinked on.

'But the inquiry in 1994 into what I had brought out into the open was a whitewash. I've been vindicated over all the revelations and allegations since then.'

The England and Wales Cricket Board welcomes 'any inquiry into any part of the game that Sir Paul Condon feels needs to be looked at, because corruption has no place in the game', said spokesman Mark Hodgson.

He confirmed that Gerard Elias QC, chairman of the ECB's disciplinary committee, is examining the claims made by Topley.

English cricket is reeling from last week's claim by India's Central Bureau of Investigation that Alec Stewart took £5,000 from a bookmaker for 'supplying information' during England's 1993 tour of India and Sri Lanka.

Condon, director of the International Cricket Council's anti-corruption unit, also warned that umpires, referees, administrators and sponsors will come under scrutiny as his six-strong team pursue their inquiries.

'We shouldn't be surprised that some people have succumbed to temptation. Huge sums of money can be made from manipulating the odds. Clearly cricket did not have enough in place to deter people,' he said.

Condon said he would bring forward recommendations for action to ensure that 'what happens on the cricket square [is] to do with skill, heroism, courage and weather conditions and not the outcome of a mobile phone call or a grubby meeting at a hotel where people have decided in advance what's going to happen'.

Investigators from Condon's unit held talks in Delhi yesterday with officials from the CBI. They took possession of evidence from CBI joint director RN Savani but refused to answer questions.

An attempt yesterday by Ajay Jajeda, one of the five Indian players named in the CBI report, to clear his name descended into chaos when Hindu nationalist demonstrators burst into his Delhi press conference and tried to pelt him with eggs.

After they were ushered away, Jajeda emerged to claim he had 'never accepted money' to underperform in a match.

fields.headline: Hoggard hogs the heroics
fields.trailText: Given that England will almost certainly need a strong contribution from their spinners if they are going to make an impact on the Test series against Pakistan, the fine showing by the Yorkshire quick bowler Matthew Hoggard in the win over the Patron's XI here was more a pleasant surprise for the touring side than a significant breakthrough (it was definitely a performance for the longer term, though).
fields.body:
Given that England will almost certainly need a strong contribution from their spinners if they are going to make an impact on the Test series against Pakistan, the fine showing by the Yorkshire quick bowler Matthew Hoggard in the win over the Patron's XI here was more a pleasant surprise for the touring side than a significant breakthrough (it was definitely a performance for the longer term, though).

Hoggard's nine wickets in the match, which England won midway through yesterday's final day by an innings and 27 runs, gave him three more than the spinners, Ashley Giles and Ian Salisbury, managed between them, although Giles's three for 38 from 16 overs helped to speed the match towards its conclusion.

Even if the admirably willing Hoggard does make it into the Test side, it will only really be as a spear carrier for Darren Gough and Andrew Caddick, who were both rested for this match, and the all-rounder Craig White. It would have suited England better if it had been Giles and Salisbury who had been the chief architects of the team's success. Salisbury seemed to have everything in his favour to do well yesterday having broken through in the Patron's XI second innings on Friday evening and having conditions that were responding to wrist spin.

But batsmen out here know all about bowling that comes out of the back of the hand and unless it is a little special they tend to be equal to it. Sadly, Salisbury wasn't special enough and although his two for 51 from 19 overs was tidy it lacked the destructiveness the England management were looking for.

Resuming 147 adrift on 49 for one, the Patron's XI lost their last eight wickets for just 83 runs in 32.3 overs with Hoggard's four for 40 taking his match figures to nine for 102. Two winters playing alongside Allan Donald and Hansie Cronje in just such conditions in Bloemfontein as he experienced here taught Hoggard all he needed to know about the art of bowling on this type of pitch.

'It was a great experience to play with Allan and Hansie and to play on flat pitches as the English professional in South Africa has got to do you good,' he said. 'It was good to be able to come into this game and stamp down my authority and I'm ready to perform if any gaps appear in the Test team.'

The victory was also a personal success for Graham Thorpe, leading England for only the second time, and a timely one with only one more warm-up match - this week's four-day game against a Governor's XI in Peshawar - before the start of the Test series in Lahore on 15 November.

Hoggard, 23, from Pudsey in Yorkshire's cricketing heartland, had been largely responsible for earning England a 196-run first-innings lead by claiming five for 62 and was soon in the thick of the action yesterday, although it was with a notable piece of fielding that he made the breakthrough. In the fifth over of the day, he showed great athleticism to run out Kamran Ali by swooping after completing his delivery stride. He then added to his own wicket tally by having opener Naved Ashraf caught behind.

Hoggard should have secured a second victim in his next over with captain Mohammad Wasim clipping off his legs to Michael Vaughan at short mid-wicket, but the chance was spilled. Wasim lasted only two more deliveries, though, Hoggard winning a leg before decision with a full-length delivery.

Left-arm spinner Giles increased the pressure on the Patron's XI before lunch, striking in his second over after replacing Hoggard to remove Salman Shah, caught down the leg side by Nixon.

Largely overshadowed by Giles in the match, Salisbury did at least begin to exert his influence after the interval and struck by having Javed Qadeer leg before. But Hoggard remained the most influential figure, mopping up further wickets before Giles completed England's victory when last man Mohammad Akram scooped high to Marcus Trescothick at mid-off.

The victory was also a personal success for Graham Thorpe, leading England for only the second time, and a timely one with only one more warm-up match - this week's four-day game against a Governor's XI in Peshawar - before the start of the Test series in Lahore on 15 November. Hoggard, 23, from Pudsey in Yorkshire's cricketing heartland, had been largely responsible for earning England a 196-run first-innings lead by claiming five for 62 and was soon in the thick of the action yesterday, although it was with a notable piece of fielding that he made the breakthrough. He then added to his own wicket tally by having opener Naved Ashraf caught behind. Wasim lasted only two more deliveries, though, Hoggard winning a leg before decision with a full-length delivery. Largely overshadowed by Giles in the match, Salisbury did at least begin to exert his influence after the interval and struck by having Javed Qadeer leg before. But Hoggard remained the most influential figure, mopping up further wickets before Giles completed England's victory when last man Mohammad Akram scooped high to Marcus Trescothick at mid-off.

fields.headline: Cricket madness Pakistan style
fields.trailText: Seven days; two thousand kilometres travelled; three one-day internationals. Cost - about £40. England lost 2-1 in the series and played disappointingly in the last two matches, but not bad for a weeks bed and board, all travelling expenses and tickets to all three matches. The attraction of watching cricket in Pakistan, other than the low cost, is that it is so important to the people. Cricket is more than just a game in Pakistan. It is an integral part of the culture and a source of great pride. To watch a match, especially a one-day international is to witness a unique sporting spectacle.
fields.body:
Seven days; two thousand kilometres travelled; three one-day internationals. Cost - about £40. England lost 2-1 in the series and played disappointingly in the last two matches, but not bad for a weeks bed and board, all travelling expenses and tickets to all three matches. The attraction of watching cricket in Pakistan, other than the low cost, is that it is so important to the people. Cricket is more than just a game in Pakistan. It is an integral part of the culture and a source of great pride. To watch a match, especially a one-day international is to witness a unique sporting spectacle.

The experience of going to a cricket match in Pakistan begins many days before the actual game. Finding tickets is a time-consuming process, especially for one-day internationals. In England spectators can obtain tickets through counties, clubs or directly from the ground. In Pakistan, prospective spectators have to go the bank and see the bank manager. In Karachi my attempts to find a ticket involved not one, but five different banks. Each time I was ushered into the managerís office only to be told that he had in fact sold out. The whole morning became more like a treasure hunt as each bank manager handed me a piece of paper with the name of a bank that possibly had tickets - it was all very hush-hush. My final port of call was an innocuous little bank down some side street.

There, I was subjected to a five-minute interrogation on my reasons for wanting to attend the game. Did I like cricket? Who was my favourite player? Is Nasser Hussain a good Muslim? Finally he relented and let me buy one of his few remaining tickets. I left the bank the proud owner of a ticket in the Wasim Bari Enclosure, all for the princely sum of 30 rupees (about forty pence in English money).

There is a great feeling of excited anticipation throughout Karachi in the days leading up to the first one day international. Everyone is talking about the game, and in particular whether the current darling of Pakistan cricket, Shahid Afridi, will play. The consensus is that he will not, as he only got married on Sunday and will have other, more important things on his mind. Everyone you talk to seems to be going to the game, from rickshaw drivers to bank managers. Only when you arrive at the ground on match day do you realise that everyone in Karachi is in fact only trying to see the game.

The dusty streets around the National Stadium are crammed with people in search of their respective entrances. Painted faces and flags are everywhere and people come up and grab my hand and welcome me to their country. This relaxed and friendly atmosphere is only interrupted by brief periods of utter chaos when certain policeman make their presence felt with a few angry lashes of their bamboo sticks. Actually getting into the ground involves much pushing and shoving and a lot of body searches by big-moustached policeman. Spectators are not allowed to bring anything into the ground. This really means nothing - no cameras, no books, no food, no plastic bottles of water and definitely no lighters or cigarettes. This no-cigarette rule means that a huge pile of cigarettes and lighters lie outside every entrance, closely guarded by some lucky policeman.

The atmosphere that greets you when you enter into the heavily barbed wire stadium is awesome, and it only gets better as the match progresses and the lights come on. It feels more football and pop concert than cricket. There is constant noise and activity in the stands. Every ball is greeted with cheers, whistles and applause. This applause is not reserved solely for the Pakistani team, but for good cricket, even if that is a one-bounce four by Graham Hick or a diving stop by Nasser Hussain. However, the biggest cheers are definitely saved for Pakistani wickets sixes. Complete pandemonium breaks out as everyone jumps up, runs around with their flags and starts to dance. This dance is difficult to describe, but it involves hopping on one leg whilst turning around and flapping you arms like a chicken. Another occasion for great excitement is when Inzamam-ul-Haq, the rather portly Pakistan batsmen, breaks into a jog whilst fielding. These short bursts of athleticism are met with a great chorus of aloo, meaning potato.

I have now watched a number of games in Pakistan, all of which have been wonderful occasions. England have played extremely well and the Pakistani fans have been incredibly friendly and welcoming. There has only been one moment of real concern since arriving in Pakistan. It took place during the second innings of one of England's warm up games. It involved a hot curry, drop-loos and complete darkness. The lesson to be learned from this little incident is, if day/night games take off in England be sure to take a torch - the stadium might not be fully geared up for spectatorís needs during the second innings.

James Davis will be writing for The Observer during the Pakistan tour.

fields.headline: Stewart joins the torment
fields.trailText: For the moment we must assume that Stewart is telling the truth even if this leaves us bewildered as to why he was named in the first place, says Vic Marks.
fields.body:
It does not say much for the ability of the cricketing community to cleanse its game that this weekend, more than five years after the stain of match-fixing had come to our attention, we still find ourselves mulling over what might or might not have happened somewhere in India in 1993. For so long the cricketing authorities seemed determined to ignore the problem. Remember that the first serious allegations, made by Mark Waugh and Shane Warne against Salim Malik in February 1995, only became public knowledge after leaks to the Sydney Morning Herald. The Australian Cricket Board would have preferred to keep the story under wraps in the hope that the problem would somehow magically evaporate. So would all the others.

It didn't and - oh so - slowly there have been attempts to ensure that the game's integrity is restored but these are so easily fractured by national allegiances. Take this week for example. In the wake of the allegations against Alec Stewart, the ECB's Chairman, Lord MacLaurin has had to backtrack - or in his eyes 'clarify' his position - about what to do with players under suspicion. Meanwhile, his opposite number in Pakistan, General Tauqir Zia, could not resist an open goal. 'They [the ECB] did not realise that if they throw stones at any country, the same thing may come back on them,' he said. Somehow the head of the ICC's Anti-Corruption Unit, Sir Paul Condon - the possessor of 'safe hands' according to Stewart - must seek to cut through national barriers in pursuit of the truth.

Stewart, by his own admission, has just endured the most harrowing few days of his career. In England he has been the focal point of discussion about the CBI's report though the allegations against him, which occupy no more than a couple of paragraphs, are piffling compared to with those against Mohammed Azharuddin, Brian Lara or Aravinda de Silva.

If it wasn't for the case of Hansie Cronje we would all be swatting away the allegations of the Indian bookmaker, Mukesh Gupta, about his dealings with Stewart as if they were no more an irritant than a persistent fly. Cronje, we thought, was the last person who might become embroiled with dubious bookmakers. We now think the same about Stewart but unfortunately for him in the wake of the revelations about Cronje, we never say 'never' again.

Stewart's denial that he has ever received money for information has been emphatic. But even if the allegations of Gupta were true, it would not have represented the end of the world for Stewart. In his testimony Gupta said that Stewart refused to fix matches. Moreover, back in 1993 when Stewart was touring India as England's vice-captain, we were unaware of the bookmaker's ploy of offering 'sweeteners' for banal information before entrapping cricketers to manipulate games. In those innocent days how many players would have scorned the chance of such easy and apparently harmless money? From WG Grace onwards cricketers have sought to maximise their earning potential and Stewart is no exception to this rule.

If Stewart had acknowledged the allegations to be true his only problem would have been explaining why he hadn't mentioned this to the authorities in the past 12 months, when the issue of match-fixing has finally come to the fore. Now he only has a problem if his denial is false. That would constitute a far greater offence than taking the money in the first place. For the moment we must assume that Stewart is telling the truth even if this leaves us bewildered why Gupta, whose association with most of the other players named in the CBI report is not in question, should name Stewart in the first place.

However uncomfortable Stewart has been feeling over the past few days, his situation is infinitely preferable to that of de Silva, Lara and Azharuddin. Gupta, upon whom the findings of the CBI report depend so heavily, alleged that de Silva and Lara both took money to underperform, a charge on a completely different scale to passing on infor mation. De Silva, who is one of the most popular cricketers in the world (they adored him when he played for Kent) and Lara, who isn't, both refute these allegations.

Azharuddin, however, seems to be sunk. He, alongside four other Indian cricketers (Jadeja, Mongia, Sharma and Prabhakar), has already been banned from playing by the Indian Board. In the report Azharuddin admits to fixing at least two one-day matches and a life ban must be on the cards. His plight encapsulates the sickness of modern cricket.

Back in 1984 when England were touring I witnessed his entry into first-class cricket. He was impossibly shy but clearly a minor genius, who scored three centuries in his first three Tests during which he would whip the ball to the legside boundary with magical wrists and as if embarrassed by his precocious talent, would stare down at his feet until the next ball arrived. Along with de Silva he was the most enchanting, if not the most productive batsman, of the past decade or more. All of which now counts for nothing. He has played more one day internationals - 334 - than any other cricketer, a statistic, I suggest, that is not unconnected with his fall from grace. A

zharuddin must bear the responsibility for his actions but he was unfortunate to play in an era when the one-day international match was so devalued. Too often in the crazy international calendar of the Nineties no one, not even the players, really cared who won or lost, but rather how much they could make out of the game.

fields.headline: Old Firm will bag it
fields.trailText: For all the glamour attached to being involved in the Old Firm scene, I have never envied any of the players who earn their living there, nor the managers of the two teams.
fields.body:
The rivalry between Rangers and Celtic is scary. I cannot think of any country in which two teams dominate the scene as much as the Old Firm do; and the fact that they operate in the same city makes the football atmosphere probably more highly charged than anywhere in the world.

For all the glamour attached to being involved in the Old Firm scene, I have never envied any of the players who earn their living there, nor the managers of the two teams.

The stick Rangers' manager Dick Advocaat has been taking is par for the course in Glasgow when one team are faring considerably better than the other. At present, Celtic are in the ascendant while Rangers - who won the title last season for the eleventh time in 12 years - have been languishing in fourth place.

The obvious explanations for Rangers not doing as well as expected - yet - are that they have had injury problems and, having won all there is to be won in Scotland, have become increasingly conscious of the need to start doing well in Europe.

It is not easy to develop a successful Champions League team in Scotland, where the depth of good players is inevitably limited and the game is very physical and hectic. However, for all their perceived problems, I would not dismiss Rangers' chances of getting the win they need over Monaco on Tuesday to reach the second stage.

The question of whether they can retain the league title is another matter, which underlines the tremendous job Martin O'Neill has done at Celtic.

Celtic have continued to play good football under Martin. But, as reflected by his teams at Leicester, it is winning that comes first with him. When discussing managers in Scotland, I have to mention Alex McLeish, my former Aberdeen team-mate, whose Hibernian team have emerged as Celtic's leading title challengers.

In his efforts to keep it going, Alex is bound to be helped to some extent by having been part of Aberdeen's title-winning teams. In addition to Aberdeen, who finished top in 1980, 1984 and 1985, the only other side to have broken the Old Firm domination of the Championship since the formation of the Premier Division 24 seasons ago have been Dundee United, in 1983.

But the reality for Alex is that Hibernian need to keep all their best players in order to maintain their challenge - not easy in these post-Bosman days - and even then, trying to keep up with clubs of the stature of Rangers and Celtic represents a losing battle.

One factor in Alex Ferguson's Championship success at Aberdeen was that he did much to break the psychological barrier that had repeatedly hampered teams in matches against the Glasgow giants.

To a great extent, he did it by putting a chip on his players' shoulders. He repeatedly drew attention to the advantages Rangers and Celtic enjoyed over clubs like ours, particularly with regards to the way the Old Firm were perceived by referees and the media.

Basically, it was all about making them feel that they were the victims of injustices - if there weren't any good cases of this, he would actually invent some - giving them what he described as a 'common cause'. However, it has to be conceded that we happened to catch Rangers and Celtic at the right time.

The Old Firm had become complacent. As by far the most powerful clubs in the country. they had become used to not having to really push themselves on the field - and I would say this was also true of them in the financial department.

The Old Firm revolution began with the appointment of Graeme Souness as manager in 1986, and his massive expenditure in bringing top English players to Ibrox. That gave Rangers the new dimension they needed, and Celtic were forced to follow suit

These clubs have become multi-faceted business empires. They have got so far ahead of the rest in Scotland that I honestly cannot see any provincial club ever winning the title again.

webTitle: Kiev block the path to millions

fields.headline: Kiev block the path to millions
fields.standfirst: Defeat in the final group game on Wednesday will cost Manchester United plc £20
fields.trailText: Defeat in the final Champions League group game next week will cost Manchester United plc £20m.
fields.body:
Manchester United will miss out on a windfall worth up to £25 million if they fail to beat Dynamo Kiev in the Champions League on Wednesday.

That is the staggering sum United could earn if they win their Group G decider at Old Trafford and stay in the competition. Never before has so much money been at stake in one match. Defeat would also blow a huge hole in the club's finances, restrict their ability to buy players and jeopardise their domination of English football.

United would bank around £25m if they went on to win the competition (in prize money, gate receipts, television revenue and additional merchandising). Failure against the Ukrainians would cost them at the very least £10m, the amount qualification for the second group stage involves, plus the chance to earn another £15m in the later big-money knockout stages.

United have to win to be sure of progressing alongside PSV Eindhoven or Anderlecht. They lie third in their group with just seven points from five games; their Dutch and Belgian rivals already have nine points each.

A draw would see United drop into the much less lucrative Uefa Cup as the third-placed team. Their nightmare scenario - a Kiev victory - would mean they finished bottom and Kiev reached the Uefa Cup instead.

Last year United made £20.9m from the Champions League despite going out in the quarter-finals to eventual winners Real Madrid. 'That's called "high-margin revenue" because £16.9m of it was pure profit. He is under pressure after selling homegrown talents such as Andrei Shevchenko and Sergei Rebrov and importing cheap replacements from Russia, which Ukrainians consider inferior footballing territory.

However, mystery surrounds where the multimillions Kiev have generated in recent years by selling players and doing well in Europe have gone. Rumours abound of criminal links to the club and of Kiev income bankrolling Surkis's own political party.

webTitle: Grecian 2000 not enough to turn England grey

fields.headline: Grecian 2000 not enough to turn England grey
fields.trailText: Panathinaikos will be through to the second round of the Champions League if they beat Juventus, so the match is being hailed as the biggest encounter in the region since the Trojan War. Or perhaps bigger.
fields.body:
This may be an apocryphal story, but it goes as follows: After Andreas Niniadis scored for Olympiakos Piraeus last weekend, he picked up a mobile phone hurled at him by a helpful opposing fan and dialled the number of Diego Maradona in Cuba.

'Hello,' said Maradona.

'Diego, is that you?' asked Niniadis.

'Who is this?' asked Maradona.

'Come on, Diego, it's me,' said Niniadis. 'Andreas from Greece. Niniadis from Olympiakos. Don't you remember me?' After more embarrassing explanations along these lines, Niniadis wished Maradona a happy fortieth birthday. Maradona, who may have forgotten that it was his birthday, said, 'You made a mistake,' and hung up.

This call probably never happened, because it is difficult to imagine a Greek footballer speaking a word of a foreign language. Even so, the conversation sums up the tragicomedy that is Greek football, because the man Maradona had never heard of is a hero in Greece.

The Greek game hopes to improve its image somewhat this Wednesday, when Panathinaikos receive Juventus in the Champions League. The Greeks will be through to the second round if they win, so the match is being hailed as the biggest encounter in the region since the Trojan War, or perhaps bigger. Olympiakos Piraeus will join Panathinaikos in the last 16 if they draw at Olympique Lyon on Tuesday.

This would delight Greek football fans, who are refreshingly unspoiled. No Greek side have ever won a European trophy, and when the national team finally qualified for a World Cup in 1994 they ended up wishing they hadn't bothered. I remember watching their practices near Boston: an outfield player would stand in goal while others blasted shots over the bar. In matches they were thrashed. Athenian bars were packed with people making obscene gestures at television sets.

It is remarkable that a reasonably prosperous European country of more than 10 million people has achieved so little in football that basketball is in danger of becoming the national sport. The best a Greek team ever managed was Panathinaikos's appearance in the European Cup final at Wembley in 1971, when they lost 2-0 to Ajax. However, in his book Champions of Europe Brian Glanville says the club 'were outrageously favoured by the French referee of their return home leg against Everton in the quarter-finals'. Joe Royle, then an Everton player, recalled how in the first match at Goodison Greek defenders would whisper in his ear, 'Athens, Athens!'

'And in Athens', records Glanville, 'Everton got nothing from the referee.'

Generally, there are so many bribery scandals in Greek football that they hardly qualify as scandals. The big clubs are traditionally owned by very rich men who use football as a way to snuggle up to government. The Olympiakos president and telecoms magnate Socrates Kokalis is a friend of the governing Pasok party, while the upper echelons of Panathinaikos, once pally with the ruling military junta, are now closer to the New Democracy party. Government contracts are worth a lot in Greece.

One foreign manager recalls frequent summonses to meet his president behind suburban Athenian train stations late at night, where he would be told which players to put in his team. Presidents also delight in suddenly buying players, and if the coach doesn't like them, well, he's never around for long anyway.

You might think all this would prompt the best Greek players to move abroad. It seldom does, and even when they do leave they usually come home fast. Grigoris Georgatos, the Olympiakos defender, joined Inter Milan a year ago, played rather well, but returned to Greece after one season desperately homesick despite having spent most of his free time in Athens. A rare Greek to have prospered abroad, the Ajax striker Nikos Machlas, admitted to having spent his first months in Holland crossing the days off a calendar. Greek footballers make English footballers look cosmopolitan.

In any case, why leave Greece? It is a delightful country with excellent pay for footballers. This summer Panathinaikos reportedly offered Teddy Sheringham a salary of £1 million net. Well-known players who fail in Spain or Italy often end up in Greece, their arrival generally prompting the newspaper headline, 'I Have Not Come for the Money'. Olympiakos currently boast the Brazilian Giovanni, while Panathinaikos have the Croat Goran Vlaovic and the Portuguese Paolo Sousa, none of whom has so far performed miracles.

It would be wrong to say that Greek fans expect too much. In fact, they expect very little. When the national team played a friendly against Austria in February, only 600 people turned up. Even Greek fans, however, had expected better than a defeat in the recent World Cup qualifier in Albania, much as it pleased hundreds of thousands of dirt-poor Albanian migrant labourers. Surely England should be able to nose ahead of Greece and finish second in the qualifying group?

fields.headline: Walsall top again
fields.trailText: Who says money is always decisive in football? Certainly not Walsall, who returned to the top of Division Two after this thrilling win against their wealthy promotion rivals.
fields.body:
Who says money is always decisive in football? Certainly not Walsall, who returned to the top of Division Two after this thrilling win against their wealthy promotion rivals.

The teams lined up as follows: in the red shirts of Walsall, £180,000; in the blue and white hoops of Reading, £3.7 million. They were also able to leave another £3m of playing talent back at the £40m Madejski Stadium.

But this disparity counted for nothing on the pitch. Reading were very strong early on. They hit the post twice, had a goal disallowed and a strong penalty appeal turned down but were hit with a sucker punch from Walsall's former Real Madrid midfielder Pedro Matias early in the second half and never quite recovered.

Walsall doubled their lead late on when Darren Byfield headed in Ian Brightwell's cross before Reading substitute Jimmy McIntyre's brilliant consolation.

Walsall manager Ray Graydon said: 'It was a cracking win, which I think we deserved for our second-half performance. Reading are a very good side. Just one of their centre-forwards cost as much as my whole team, by a long way, so I'm very pleased. This sends out a message.'

His Reading counterpart, Alan Pardew, was unhappy with the officials. 'Walsall are a good team and the goals were well-taken but I was disappointed with the referee,' he said. 'It was a big occasion and he was found wanting.'

As an intriguing footnote, Ray Graydon swapped goalkeepers at half-time because he felt Carl Emberson was not performing well enough. He said: 'It is not something many managers would have done, but those are the decisions I am paid to make.'

Emberson's replacement, James Walker, brilliantly tipped substitute Jamie Cureton's late effort on to the post but could do nothing when McIntyre curled in a superb 25-yard shot in injury time.

webTitle: United show the good and bad

fields.headline: United show the good and bad
fields.trailText: United show the good and bad against below-strength City.
fields.body:
They have been described as the Premiership's warlords but yesterday Manchester United needed to do little more than shout 'boo' at below-strength Coventry City's pacifists to accumulate another three points that keep them at the top of the table. They will need to be back in belligerent mood for the more demanding task of beating Dynamo Kiev to stay in the Champions' League on Wednesday.

These are strange days for United and this match showed exactly why. They remain pacey and potent going forward, particularly through David Beckham and Ryan Giggs on the flanks, as a two-goal half-time lead showed. In defence, though, there is a new vulnerability - seen in the concession of an out-of-the-Sky-Blue goal - that better-quality attacking teams are beginning to relish. Coventry are not one of them, however.

They could hardly have been expected to be yesterday, mind. Without three injured strikers, they were mostly toothless. A stronger, more self-confident side might have profited from United's carelessness and generosity in allowing them back into the game and prised a point. As Sir Alex Ferguson said: 'They didn't have enough with the team they had out to come back from 2-1.'

What Coventry should have been expected to do was compete more intensely as compensation for the gap in talent and resources. In football, the meek do not inherit the earth. 'In the first half we played the reputation of Manchester United,' said their manager Gordon Strachan.

Only when he introduced three more aggressive substitutes, notably John Eustace, was United's practice-match comfort challenged, Roy Keane's hamstring previously enjoying some gentle exercise. Keane even had to make a tackle, a nasty one on Eustace, which might have earned more than a yellow card. Graham Poll, indeed, upset home fans who perceived big-club bias - 'I was there for five years. I know how it is,' said Strachan - but in reality the away team needed little aid.

The first goal was United at their best, inflicted on Coventry like a snakebite. Paul Scholes swept a pass out to Beckham who crossed instantly to the near post where Andy Cole was the most alert and his flick was past Chris Kirkland in an instant. 'A great goal. Over in a matter of seconds,' said Ferguson.

Soon after, Paul Williams foolishly fouled Giggs some 20 yards out. Beckham did not have to be at his best from the free-kick to score, the shot travelling through the wall and squirming under Kirkland. Cole wasted two good chances to increase the lead and Beckham was just wide with another curling free kick. Then, remarkably, Coventry had an attack. Then, astonishingly, they scored.

The substitute Paul Telfer curled in a corner, which Gary Breen headed goalwards and another substitute, Ysrael Zuniga, glanced home. Zuniga may be making a play to rival Michael Bentine and Paddington Bear as the most celebrated Peruvian to come to this country.

How Strachan must have envied Dwight Yorke and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer coming off the bench, Yorke almost ending lingering doubt with a shot drilled against the inside of a post. It was United's eighth win in nine Premiership visits to Highfield Road. They would probably swap most of them for one on Wednesday.

webTitle: Smith's 'naming and shaming' brings right result for Palace

fields.headline: Smith's 'naming and shaming' brings right result for Palace
fields.trailText: Smith's 'naming and shaming' brings right result for Palace.
fields.body:
The jury may still need more convincing that Crystal Palace's problems have been solved by manager Alan Smith's route one approach to naming and shaming his under-achieving players.

But in the space of eight days, they have responded to being branded 'a bunch of lazy, sloppy whingers' with three emphatic performances which certainly made a mockery of their humble standing.

A battling draw at Bolton was followed in mid-week by a rousing Worthington Cup victory at Leicester.

Yesterday, Palace took apart a Sheffield Wednesday side entertaining thoughts of arresting their own slide to register a first league victory in nearly two months.

Wednesday had taken seven points from three games and made particularly satisfying progress in the Cup at the expense of Sheffield United. But according to manager Paul Jewell one or two players had started to believe their own publicity - and the result was a good spanking.

Any side can be forgiven for conceding one goal to a corner. Letting in a second becomes rather careless. Surrendering a third is inexcusable. That was the story of Wednesday's defensive afternoon, punished by eager and accurate finishing.

Smith would have been entitled to gloat a little. Instead, his comments were all rather low key. 'What has been said has been well documented and I don't want to add any more,' he declared. 'This is a start, but no more. We have some difficult games coming up. I just hope this has given the players the belief in the way this club wants to go. In those three matches I have used 21 of them and I think we now have a real force among that number.'

Jewell acknowledge the absence of injured defender Ashley Westwood, but admitted: 'This was a case of after the Lord Mayor's Show. They were physically stronger than we were. The league is our bread and butter and we should have been up for it. Maybe it's the kick up the backside we needed.'

Palace led from the third minute, with Tommy Black's corner headed on by Fan Zhiyi and nodded in at the far post by Dougie Freedman for his third goal in three games.

When Steve Staunton delivered another corner it was Jamie Pollock who got the knock-on for Clinton Morrison to score his third in as many games.

Pollock scored his first for the club when Black's corner from the opposite flank was helped on by Zhiyi, and although Jewell shuffled his pack at half-time, his team were killed off by a fourth two minutes into the second half.

Pollock, playing a captain's role seized on to a clearance to thrash a low 25-yarder beyond Kevin Pressman.

Palace might easily have had more, such was the command they exercised.

Former Wimbledon striker Efan Ekoku, on loan to Wednesday from the Swiss team Grasshoppers, did manage to squeeze some consolation when Zhiyi brought him down in the area and Gerald Sibon slid in the penalty. But with only nine minutes remaining Wednesday had no chance of building on the goal. Neither did they deserve to do so.

Palace were superior in all departments and while there is still much work to do they at least seem finally to have their season up and running.

fields.headline: Shearer shades it
fields.trailText: Shearer seals it on Robson's big day.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James's Park
fields.body:
Newcastle United manager Bobby Robson enjoyed this one. 'It's not been a bad day for me,' he smiled afterwards - and Robson was not just talking about his team's first Premiership victory at home since the end of August.

He had also seen ample evidence that Ipswich, the other love of his football life after his 14 years at Portman Road, are again in safe hands under George Burley. Burley, an assured full-back during that successful era in East Anglia, might even have emerged with a draw in this encounter with the man who once controlled his playing career.

But a controversial penalty won by Alan Shearer eventually ended Town's attempt to extend their unbeaten run to seven games - and Burley couldn't even win the verbal exchange which inevitably followed. Ipswich were upset at referee Alan Wily's decision to award the 67th-minute penalty after Shearer's surge into the area was halted by Mark Venus's challenge.

'The ref was 50 or 60 yards away, the crowd shouts, Alan Shearer falls and he gives a penalty,' said Burley. 'Mark didn't think it was a penalty and, if it had been at the other end, I know which way it would have gone.'

It was an impassioned argument which Robson dismantled with one sentence. 'Alan will tell you a different story - and he might have been a bit closer than George,' said the Newcastle manager.

Not that Robson was overly impressed with Mr Wiley. He questioned why Venus was not sent off - a valid point given that he was the last man - but added: 'So many strange decisions were given out there today that I'm not surprised he sent the guy off.'

fields.headline: Savage is the Maine man
fields.trailText: Taylor stays flavour of the month as Savage shines.
fields.body:
Dressing-room cliques, card games for £10,000 a hand, senior stars shunning each other. Managing England may present its challenges for Leicester's Peter Taylor later this month, but it promises to provide more interest than his club can currently offer.

Another day brought another thoroughly professional performance from Leicester while an intelligent piece of finishing from Robbie Savage kept his team a creditable third in the Premiership. It is precisely the sort of result that has rendered Taylor English football's flavour of the moment, a manager with international potential. But entertainment? A goal tally of 4-1 in Leicester's six away League games to date probably best answers that.

'Our goals-against record has been excellent,' said Taylor. 'And when they work as hard as they did today you can see why we have it. It would just be nice to take our chances when we do get them and we had a couple near the end.'

Most profligate was Leicester substitute Arnar Gunn-lagsson who ran directly into Steve Howey late in the game, wasting a two-on-one break for the visitors although it mattered not, the outcome having been decided by Savage 10 minutes into the half.

Neil Lennon rolled a short free-kick, Savage's initial right-foot shot was blocked by Jeff Whitley and Savage switched to his left before putting a 20-yard shot into the bottom corner of Nicky Weaver's goal.

The goal capped an orgy of goalmouth action in comparison to the opening half in which caution, a poor surface and a distressingly poor level of technical ability accounted for a moribund period of unspeakable mediocrity.

When Tim Flowers needed lengthy treatment to his back after a tumble, his absence would probably not have been noted if he had done the sensible thing and left the field in protest. As it was, he battled on to the interval and allowed understudy Simon Royce to participate in an improved second half.

Early on, a Matt Elliott header was turned around the far post by Weaver, Paul Dickov quickly responded with a superb pass for Paulo Wanchope whose first-time shot was smothered by Royce and the keeper was later required to tip over a dangerous Wanchope header.

At least Joe Royle's side played better and survival still looks comfortably within their grasp. 'I don't think it was an enthralling game,' said Royle with measured understatement. 'But Peter has the three points and he'll be enthralled by that.'

fields.headline: Plain sailing for Charlton
fields.trailText: Ruthless Charlton see off toothless Bradford.
fields.body:
It has not been the best of weeks in Yorkshire, and most of the county will understand how Bradford now feel. A bright start by Charlton submerged a visiting team simply unable to stem the flow of defeats away from home.

Chris Hutchings' side are looking increasingly out of their depth at this level - they have now played each of the Premiership's promoted sides, and they have lost every time. These two sides had never previously met at this level and, after a sorry display that ended in the last-minute dismissal of their assistant manager Stuart McCall, it may be a while before the Bantams return to the Valley.

Stan Collymore stole the pre-match attention. And he didn't even have to be here to do so. After his astonishing debut goal against Leeds, the troubled striker was withdrawn against Newcastle in midweek and did not even make the trip to the Valley.

Also out was Benito Carbone, with 36-year-old Dean Saunders preferred to the underperforming Italian. Whatever the reasoning, Bradford were toothless. Charlton, meanwhile, were ruthless.

Twice in the first 20 minutes, Graham Stuart breached Bradford's pretence of a defence, which simply could not cope with his intelligent running from deep. In the fourth minute, Mathias Svensson found him sadly unmarked to advance into the area, draw Matt Clarke and square the ball to leave Jonatan Johansson with the simplest of tap-ins.

Bradford did not learn their lesson. Fourteen minutes later, Stuart picked up the ball 50 yards out and advanced untroubled to the edge of the box, played a sweet one-two with Johansson and chipped the ball over Clarke. While Ward twice came close for the away side, only wayward shooting and Clarke's agility saved Bradford from first-half humiliation.

Charlton probably believed that the game was then won. That would certainly explain their second-half performance - where they had built their lead on pace, aggression and hunger, in the second period they seemed to have had their fill.

They should, though, have extended their lead in the 54th minute when Chris Powell's low centre was inexplicably missed by Svensson. Bradford returned the favour six minutes later - both Ward and Saunders failing to connect with Jamie Lawrence's cross.

fields.headline: Miller gives Rangers high five
fields.standfirst: Round-up
fields.trailText: Rangers in general, and striker Kenny Miller in particular, gave a stunning reply to the criticism of the team's recent performances yesterday.
fields.body:
Rangers in general, and striker Kenny Miller in particular, gave a stunning reply to the criticism of the team's recent performances yesterday.

They thrashed St Mirren 7-1, and Miller got his name in the record books by scoring five of the goals. The last Scot to do that in a top-flight match in his home country was Paul Sturrock for Dundee United in 1984.

It was difficult to believe that Miller, who was signed from Hibernian in the summer, was making only his third appearance in Rangers' starting line-up, and that he has spent their European nights watching the action from the stands.

The win ended a run of three successive league reverses for the champions and manager Dick Advocaat added: 'In the first half, and in parts of the second, the way we played, the movement, the possession, and the way we scored the goals, was good quality. It will give the players a lift and give them the confidence that they can still do it.'

Before the kick-off, much of the attention was focused on the return of Michael Mols to Rangers' starting line-up - a major boost to their hopes of beating Monaco in the Champions League on Tuesday. But it quickly switched to Miller. Showing the confidence emanating from his recent goals against St Johnstone and Dundee United, he put Rangers ahead after only two minute. From that point on, he and his colleagues had a ball.

With St Mirren having difficulty getting out of their own half, Miller headed in an Arthur Numan cross after 24 minutes and completed his hat-trick a minute later from a cross by Jorge Albertz. He made it 4-0 after 32 minutes, and although Ricky Gillies replied for the visitors just before half-time, they were inevitably sunk without trace. In addition to Miller, the other scorers were the substitutes, Billy Dodds and Neil McCann.

There was more gloom for bottom-of-the table Dundee United at Motherwell. They had Jim Lauchlan sent off and lost 2-1. Dunfermline won 2-0 at St Johnstone.

fields.headline: Home guard fails Boro
fields.trailText: Henry shaves Arsenal past 10-man Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
Perhaps Arsene Wenger felt sorry for Bryan Robson, a manager under pressure but an English one. A big defeat here might have finally made Robson's position untenable, with Manchester United to come next week, and this should have been a big defeat.

Playing against 10 men for over an hour, after Mark Crossley was dismissed for a professional foul when conceding the penalty which brought the only goal, Arsenal cut through a pedestrian home side but were unable to supply the finish of last week.

Wenger did not even use any substitutes when things went worryingly slack in the second half. He could surely have exposed a tiring Boro by throwing on Kanu or Sylvain Wiltord, but just used Lauren, three minutes from the end.

This was Boro's fifth defeat in a row, but at least Robson can be proud of the fight. There was no dissatisfaction from the terraces at the end, only admiration for a plucky scrap against overwhelming odds. 'With 11 men the crowd was against Middlesbrough,' Wenger said. 'With 10 men the crowd got behind them, and we were a little too cautious.'

Boro were one of the first Premiership teams to look overseas for inspiration, and the £78m Bryan Robson has spent in the last six years has been spread around several continents. The amazing thing is how essentially English Boro remain. They played with a grit and determination which was commendable but nowhere near good enough.

Not against Arsenal, whose pace and stealth in attack gives them an almost unfair advantage against yeoman defending. Boro hit them with everything in the opening minutes, and were unlucky to see Lee Dixon clear Gary Pallister's header off the line and Phil Stamp twice go close, but Arsenal shrugged it off.

The goal was ostensibly a result of sloppy Boro defending, with Pallister unwisely passing across the face of his goal to Steve Vickers who was not expecting the ball, but in fact was down to Arsenal's sharpness when not in possession. Pallister could not play the obvious pass back to his goalkeeper because he was aware Thierry Henry was lurking for the intercept, and the reason Vickers took his eye off the ball at the crucial moment was that Freddie Ljungberg had anticipated the pass and was already arriving. The Arsenal man won out and advanced into the penalty area to be brought down by Crossley, who could have few complaints at the red card which followed. Robson sacrificed Hamilton Ricard to bring on substitute goalkeeper Marlon Beresford, who had no chance with Henry's penalty but made two excellent saves before the interval.

Arsenal's tendency to over-elaborate helped keep the score down, but Ljungberg should have scored after Boro were caught in possession again, before an outrageously casual backheel in his own half by Noel Whelan saw Henry miss the target when scoring looked easier.

The Frenchman missed by a greater distance when set up by Dennis Bergkamp five minutes later, then saw Beres- ford save bravely after he had gone past the Boro defence for the umpteenth time. Parlour almost hit the corner flag from one of Henry's pull-backs from the byline and Henry struck a post at the end, so it was cheeky of Robson to suggest his side had been unlucky.

But at least the Boro manager was able to confirm there is no need for Terry Venables. 'I know I've got 100 per cent backing from everyone at the club, and on today's evidence that includes the players,' he said. 'United won't be easy, but we are hoping to kickstart our season with the home games against Leicester and Bradford, when we should have all our players back.'

fields.headline: George still spurred on
fields.trailText: Amy Lawrence's White Hart Lane verdict.
fields.body:
What a difference a win makes? To the boo boys, as George Graham calmly acknowledges, it makes none whatsoever. But the Tottenham manager is never one to shirk a challenge; this is the man who called for the army to deal with an ugly mob of Millwall supporters when cutting his managerial teeth down at the Den.

Graham is patently more interested in the opinion of his chairman, his players, and the majority of supporters who put backing the team ahead of hacking at an unloved manager. Well, they certainly did yesterday, a factor which Graham acknowledged helped Tottenham to a vital victory. 'They deserve a pat on the back today,' he purred, smirking as only George Graham can. It will have amused him that the only voices singing 'Sack the board' and 'Georgie is a Gooner' came from Wearside.

When the Tottenham lynch mob are in full voice you feel that ominous vibration in the air but if the general mood of the crowd yesterday was anything to go by, it is a small faction. Although hardly buoyant, the faithful happily accentuated the positive.

A season ticket holder on his way out quipped 'Graham out' with such a big smile on his face it was impossible to detect whether he was being ironic or really meant it while being simultaneously happy to win. Either way it has to be progress.

Confidence teeters on a knife edge at the Lane. When Sunderland were awarded a penalty all that latent frustration seemed set to detonate. It flew over the bar, and when Spurs dashed off to take the lead suddenly the mood was sweetness and light. Tellingly, when Don Hutchison equalised the supporters didn't turn on the players as they have of late. 'That was very important,' added Graham.

Is his message getting through? While the fans remain split about whether the Sugar-Graham double act can brew another vintage side what they need above all is some reassurance Spurs are on the right track. They have not yet seen enough consistency, or sparks of inspiration, to quell fears they are stagnating in the land of mediocrity. Make no mistake this was a critical result, but edging a tough encounter at home to a Sunderland side who don't travel well doesn't disguise the size of the job ahead.

None the less, Graham still aims to meet his basic objective of a top-six finish, hoping this admirably determined performance will prove a turning point: 'We have a lot of good players to come back so if we can pick up results until then I don't see why not.'

Nothing will irk him more than being dubbed a failure, especially here, where his critics need no invitation to use his Arsenal past to question his commitment. Nasty though the brickbats are, you sense part of him secretly enjoys it. It only spurs him on.

fields.headline: Beattie sinks Blues
fields.trailText: Super Saints late show kills off Chelsea revival.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri is still struggling to get his message across in Chelsea's multi-lingual dressing room so it does not help when his players turn a deaf ear to each other too.

After playing their way back from a two-goal deficit, Chelsea squandered a chance to claim their first Premiership away win since April Fools' Day by conceding a decisive 90th-minute goal to James Beattie's blockbuster free-kick.

Chelsea had had a similar opportunity at the other end a few minutes previously. But Gianfranco Zola and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink fell into an argument as to how the kick should be taken and who should take it. Zola stropped off, Hasselbaink coaxed him back and they then combined to make a complete hash of it, failing to get a shot in at all.

Chelsea's Italian manager Ranieri explained: 'They did not understand each other. We were in a good offensive position and either of them could have taken it, but, in the end, they went for the worst solution.'

And with that went Chelsea's last good chance to win the game and Southampton took full advantage by going up the other end to claim only their second home win of the season to climb out of the relegation zone.

As Ranieri so accurately put it: 'There were two different halves in this match.' Southampton, without a goal in their three previous games, were good value for a two-goal lead and more at half-time.

Beattie struck his first goal, and Southampton's first in four matches, in the third minute to knock Chelsea out of their early strut. The move had its origins in a Matt Oakley dummy, which released Wayne Bridge on the left; his driven cross curled beyond the stooping frame of Chelsea defender John Terry and into the path of Beattie's run to the far post.

Hoddle's side were good value for their second, rather messy, goal after 37 minutes. Chelsea failed to clear a Bridge free-kick and the ball eventually bounced to the feet of Jo Tessem to turn over the line from a couple of yards out. Southampton could then have buried the match had Chris Marsden's effort gone in off a post.

Chelsea were fortunate to go into the break still in the game. Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle said: 'We should have had the game buried by then, but Chelsea showed the difference between a £40 million squad and a £6 million one in the second half.'

The visitors were indeed transformed after the break as they finally began to channel their frustration positively. Sam Dalla Bona brought out the best from keeper Paul Jones when he belted a 30-yard effort towards the top corner of the net. That was their first shot on target, though, and Southampton studiously stood their ground.

But a goal had begun to look inevitable by the time Dennis Wise pulled a goal back in the 68th minute, hooking in the rebound of a blocked Gus Poyet shot.

The equaliser followed nine minutes later when Poyet headed powerfully in at the far post from another pin-point Zola cross from the left.

It remained one-way traffic, and there was that free-kick chance for Chelsea, until the game entered time added on at the end when Wise conceded a free-kick 10 yards outside the penalty area. Beattie struck a venomous shot to score the winner with his second goal of the game and the season.

While a Chelsea winner at that stage would have been a touch unjust, their defeat was hard to fathom.

Zola stropped off, Hasselbaink coaxed him back and they then combined to make a complete hash of it, failing to get a shot in at all. Chelsea's Italian manager Ranieri explained: 'They did not understand each other. We were in a good offensive position and either of them could have taken it, but, in the end, they went for the worst solution.' And with that went Chelsea's last good chance to win the game and Southampton took full advantage by going up the other end to claim only their second home win of the season to climb out of the relegation zone. As Ranieri so accurately put it: 'There were two different halves in this match.' Southampton, without a goal in their three previous games, were good value for a two-goal lead and more at half-time. Beattie struck his first goal, and Southampton's first in four matches, in the third minute to knock Chelsea out of their early strut. The move had its origins in a Matt Oakley dummy, which released Wayne Bridge on the left; his driven cross curled beyond the stooping frame of Chelsea defender John Terry and into the path of Beattie's run to the far post. Hoddle's side were good value for their second, rather messy, goal after 37 minutes. Chelsea failed to clear a Bridge free-kick and the ball eventually bounced to the feet of Jo Tessem to turn over the line from a couple of yards out. Southampton could then have buried the match had Chris Marsden's effort gone in off a post. Chelsea were fortunate to go into the break still in the game. Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle said: 'We should have had the game buried by then, but Chelsea showed the difference between a £40 million squad and a £6 million one in the second half.' The visitors were indeed transformed after the break as they finally began to channel their frustration positively. Sam Dalla Bona brought out the best from keeper Paul Jones when he belted a 30-yard effort towards the top corner of the net. That was their first shot on target, though, and Southampton studiously stood their ground. But a goal had begun to look inevitable by the time Dennis Wise pulled a goal back in the 68th minute, hooking in the rebound of a blocked Gus Poyet shot. The equaliser followed nine minutes later when Poyet headed powerfully in at the far post from another pin-point Zola cross from the left. It remained one-way traffic, and there was that free-kick chance for Chelsea, until the game entered time added on at the end when Wise conceded a free-kick 10 yards outside the penalty area. Beattie struck a venomous shot to score the winner with his second goal of the game and the season. While a Chelsea winner at that stage would have been a touch unjust, their defeat was hard to fathom.

webTitle: Burial party left with clean spades

fields.headline: Burial party left with clean spades
fields.trailText: Spurs bounce back to lift pressure on Graham.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Tottenham's fans came to bury George Graham and his side but but were praising them to the rooftops at the end of a hard-fought and thrilling victory. The White Hart Lane faithful - or should that be fickle? - have been making their protests against manager Graham and chairman Alan Sugar loud and clear following a slide down the Premiership and humiliation at home to Birmingham in the Worthington Cup. But this win, and the committed manner in which it was achieved, was just the tonic Tottenham and their supporters needed, and the threatened protests never materialised.

Fired up from the start, Spurs matched Sunderland man for man and tackle for tackle, and got their reward when Chris Armstrong scored the winning goal shortly after going on as substitute for his first appearance of the season. Even the dismissal of left-back Ben Thatcher in the closing minutes, for his second yellow card, could not dampen the mood of the camp. They even applauded Ramon Vega, an obvious target of derision after some abject performances in place of the injured Sol Campbell as Tottenham's defence became unlike any sort of rearguard associated with Graham.

The Scot's response was true to his stereotype - he put a extra man at the back. Luke Young was called in as the ' catenaccio' - or bolt - behind Vega and Chris Perry, and the England under-21 defender certainly kept Kevin Phillips under lock and key for most of the game. Last season's golden-boot winner has found it harder this time around, with only four Premiership goals so far, and he squandered a golden chance in the 37th minute.

With the natives growing restless after seeing their side's early rampage come to nothing, Sunderland were awarded a penalty when Vega handled the ball inside the area for the second week running. Phillips sent goalkeeper Neil Sullivan the wrong way but also put his shot the wrong side of the bar. As Peter Reid said afterwards, 'I felt the crowd were starting to get at them and it would have been interesting if we'd scored then.'

That mistake was compounded when Tim Sherwood put Tottenham ahead a minute before half-time, shooting in from close range after Steve Clemence's corner had rebounded off defender Jody Craddock. It was no less than Spurs deserved after Thomas Sorensen had made impressive saves from a Les Ferdinand header, a Darren Anderton shot and a Ramon Vega flick - the pick a close-range save to tip over a thumping Ferdinand volley, and as Graham admitted: 'I thought it was going to be one of those days.' Sorensen was certainly less busy in the second half than Sullivan, who was given little chance when Don Hutchison rose unopposed at the far post to head home Michael Gray's deep free-kick from the left after 63 minutes.

But Spurs regained the lead 15 minutes later shortly after Armstrong replaced Sergei Rebrov, who was struggling for fitness. An ankle injury had kept Armstrong out of action since the summer, but he showed no signs of ring rust as he raced on to Sherwood's fine pass to slide a shot under Sorensen for the winner, leaving his team-mates, manager and supporters to celebrate.

'Armstrong didn't know he was going to be involved until this morning and I was pleased for him. All the players deserve credit for their commitment and for coping with the change of formation. 'We've been leaking a few goals recently and I thought we need to tighten up a bit.'
