fields.headline: Going for a Burton
fields.trailText: Stressed Out | Black Bear Rescue | Little Bird | Equinox: The Science of Stress | Fat Friends | Ruby | Josie's Journey | The Weakest Link: Champions League BBC1
fields.body:
Stressed Out C4
Black Bear Rescue BBC1
Little Bird ITV
Equinox: The Science of Stress C4
Fat Friends ITV
Ruby BBC2
Josie's Journey BBC1
The Weakest Link: Champions League BBC1

Obviously, schedules can't be expected to take into account fearsome acts of God, but in a stressful week there seemed to be a great deal of extra stress-inducing TV. On Sunday night, for example, as the nation tied Toto to a door handle and dug out that pair of ruby slippers last worn in autumn 1987, Channel 4 devoted an hour-and-a-half to the horrors of working at Leeds City Council's One Stop Shop, where 14 per cent of the workforce were diagnosed as suffering from something close to clinical depression.

Like a latter-day Kingdom of Oz, the modern front office was awash with chirpy mission statements while the backroom resembled a set from Terry Gilliam's Brazil: wonky filing-cabinets in battleship grey and lighting that allowed even the perkiest of personnel to assume the pallor of the recently deceased. But, happily, after administering a Poppins-ish dose of flip-charts, questionnaires and sugar-coated homilies, a pair of stress-management gurus managed to drag most of the workforce back from the metaphorical window ledge.

Even though, leaves on the line and gridlocked motorways notwithstanding, watching Stressed Out probably ensured high levels of miserablist absenteeism the following morning.

No, on a Sunday night we don't want too much Cortisol pumping around our systems, so it was probably less disturbing to switch to BBC1's Black Bear Rescue, where Amanda Burton was to be found playing with orphaned black bear cubs in Idaho. A celebrity getting up close and personal with telegenic beasties is, I suspect, the dumbed-down future of wildlife documentaries, if only because the old-fashioned, hardcore teeth-and-claws stuff is becoming far too depressing.

Earlier on Sunday, for example, in BBC2's Wild strand, we had seen hungry, tranquillised polar bears being airlifted away from their globally warmed (and therefore swiftly melting) Canadian ice-floes, followed by Rajasthani tigers dodging poachers keen to sell their aphrodisiacal penises to the Japanese. But why Amanda? Other than, perhaps, to reveal that, contrary to the evidence of every single episode of Silent Witness, she is entirely capable of smiling, preferably while stroking a big (tranquillised) bear and describing it as smelling 'piney, cosy, just like you'd expect a bear to be, really'.

Still, Burton's ability to grin like a great big girly failed to be exploited any further in Wednesday's Little Bird, in which she was back to her old routine. If there were any Baftas for sitting pensively inside a car in the rain, Burton could expect to be nominated several times over (she even snuck a quick one into Black Bear Rescue), but in Little Bird - a turgid, ponderous, strangely unemotional drama about adoption, in which she played a social worker - Burton gave us quite a few variations on the themes of pensive, ever-so-slightly-angry and possibly-a-little-bit-sad, plus one or two completely-inscrutables, all in profile, in a car, in the rain.

Admittedly, it wasn't Amanda's fault that this one-off ITV drama had followed hard on the heels of BBC1's riveting adoption documentary series, Love Is Not Enough, but it was unfortunate that her character, Rachel, parroted the line again. Perhaps 'Love is not enough...' is the mission statement Blu-Tacked to the walls of adoption agencies?

In Monday's Equinox: The Science of Stress, the second of C4's 'Stop, Go Home' series, we learned that Cortisol was a very useful hormone in the days when we needed to escape from lions, but somewhat less so if you're stuck in front of a call centre's crashing computer screen. Today we live in 'a stress culture' in which 'technology is pushing us forward faster than we can adapt', which will have come as a surprise to, well, almost nobody. The only thing to do, apparently, is to 'craft a lifestyle to optimise our happiness'.

Using actors playing a high-powered lawyer and his wife, a working mother, tips for 'optimising happiness' included chucking your mobile phone into the nearest swollen river, not accessing e-mails on planes, ignoring your boss's wholly unreasonable request to turn up for a meeting when you've just got off a long-haul flight on your wedding anniversary, and enjoying your downtime by reading a John Grisham, rather than Brad Thrust Jr's Ten Steps to Managerial Mightiness.

Presumably, for those of us whose lives do not closely resemble a 1980s advertisement for British Airways Club Class, some homespun mission statements Blu-Tacked to the workstation may suffice: 'Work Is Not Enough', perhaps, or 'Pass The Prozac'.

Incidentally, the latter got a brand name-check in last week's otherwise excellent Fat Friends, when one character offered another 'a Prozac, if it'll help...' Please don't try this at home, children: treating stress with 'a Prozac' would be only slightly less helpful than a shot of Paracetamol or a weekend seminar by Brad Thrust.

Reassuring, though, to know that the show's writer, Kay Mellor, hasn't succumbed to medicated depression, which is more than can be said for most of Ruby Wax's Tuesday night dinner guests on Ruby - Roseanne, Lynda La Plante and David Baddiel, who dished up delicious dinner-party topics such as the pros and cons of anal sex and the fact that being bonkersly successful and having loads of money just doesn't make you very happy at all, really. Given the high whinge-quotient, this was still hugely entertaining, but perhaps a spoonful of medicine would help all that unpalatable sugary celebrity go down - a day optimising some latent happiness by working at Leeds City Council's One Stop Shop, for example.

But even if you spent most of last week in a dinghy, rowing down the high street (and, incidentally, what was Steve Redgrave doing when the emergency services needed him? Announcing his retirement, that's what), moaning was not an option between the hours of 10.30 and 11.30 on Wednesday night, during Josie's Journey, in which the survivor of the brutal attack that killed her mother, Lin, and sister, Megan, revealed herself to be a refreshingly unsaintly, engagingly stroppy 13-year-old with a smile even bigger than Amanda Burton's.

At times this was an unbearably poignant documentary, notably when Josie's father Shaun broke down at Lin and Megan's simple grave, but at others it left a slightly bitter taste. Despite a mutually beneficial 'relationship' with both the Sun and the Daily Mail (they get the Josie exclusives, the Russells get cash for her trust fund) and the savvy acknowledgement that 'a drip-drip-drip of little stories is enough to keep the media at bay...', it was also made clear by Shaun that '[Josie] is at the point of wanting to move away from further media offers' (she swiftly rejected an invitation to open a fête with a straightforward, non-negotiable and Kevin The Teenager-ish 'boring!').

At the end of the programme, however, there was a plug for the accompanying BBC book, written by Shaun, and so one gets the feeling that, like the parents of Sarah Payne, Josie's father uses a sympathetic media, when it suits, as a balm for his indescribable loss. Josie herself had the last word, dismissing her bravery with a shrug and suggesting that, in the future, 'I'll just ask the press people to go away and leave me alone.' Nice try, Josie - but they will never leave you alone.

Wrong channel, right time: on Thursday night, while solicitor-turned-postwoman Kate Heusser was becoming only the second contestant - and the first woman - to win £500,000 on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, I was over on BBC1, gripped while watching mild-mannered Margaret rack up a massive £7,600 in last week's second edition of The Weakest Link: Champion's League. 'I've never seen a cheque like that in my life, ever...' she said, blinking like one of Wonderland's dormice. And while she could easily have gone the distance on WWTBAM , I'm not sure she would have looked any more delighted with the result.

Incidentally, I was 'Whassuped?' three times last week (by middle-class, middle-youth, white English people. And the next one who tries it will, indeed, find out 'whassup'), but received only one 'You are the weakest link. Goodbye!' - though I fear it's still early days.

Despite a mutually beneficial 'relationship' with both the Sun and the Daily Mail (they get the Josie exclusives, the Russells get cash for her trust fund) and the savvy acknowledgement that 'a drip-drip-drip of little stories is enough to keep the media at bay...', it was also made clear by Shaun that '[Josie] is at the point of wanting to move away from further media offers' (she swiftly rejected an invitation to open a fête with a straightforward, non-negotiable and Kevin The Teenager-ish 'boring!'). At the end of the programme, however, there was a plug for the accompanying BBC book, written by Shaun, and so one gets the feeling that, like the parents of Sarah Payne, Josie's father uses a sympathetic media, when it suits, as a balm for his indescribable loss. Josie herself had the last word, dismissing her bravery with a shrug and suggesting that, in the future, 'I'll just ask the press people to go away and leave me alone.' Nice try, Josie - but they will never leave you alone. Wrong channel, right time: on Thursday night, while solicitor-turned-postwoman Kate Heusser was becoming only the second contestant - and the first woman - to win £500,000 on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, I was over on BBC1, gripped while watching mild-mannered Margaret rack up a massive £7,600 in last week's second edition of The Weakest Link: Champion's League. 'I've never seen a cheque like that in my life, ever...' she said, blinking like one of Wonderland's dormice. And while she could easily have gone the distance on WWTBAM , I'm not sure she would have looked any more delighted with the result. Incidentally, I was 'Whassuped?' three times last week (by middle-class, middle-youth, white English people. And the next one who tries it will, indeed, find out 'whassup'), but received only one 'You are the weakest link. Goodbye!' - though I fear it's still early days.

fields.headline: Bohèmes on seats...
fields.trailText: La Bohème (Leoncavallo) | La Bohème (Puccini)
fields.body:
La Bohème (Leoncavallo) English National Opera, Coliseum, London WC2
La Bohème (Puccini), Glyndebourne Touring Opera, Glyndebourne, Sussex

When you first dip a toe into operatic waters, the mysteries of Cav and Pag (as you assume them to be written) can take a while to unravel. Are they an opera or a pair of tenors, an Italianate Punch and Judy or a musical Comedy of Errors? In fact they bear no relation to each other, being nicknames for two short operas by different composers which work well as a double bill. Mascagni, who wrote Cavalleriana Rusticana, later achieved a degree of notoriety by chumming up with Mussolini and writing triumphal music for Fascist rallies. He also composed a headily perfumed opera called Iris (recently revived) in which the heroine drowns herself in a drain.

Leoncavallo's heartfelt Pagliacci won him fame. Yet today his name tends only to crop up in answers to quiz questions such as 'Who wrote the "other" Bohème ?' or 'What aria was the first record to sell a million copies?' ('Vesti la giubba/On with the motley', sung by Caruso in 1907).

Despite a respectable career, his life was a series of might-have-beens and near-hits, the most famous of which was an opera based, like Puccini's, on Murger's picaresque novel, Scènes de la vie de bohéme.

After a public dispute over who had hit on the idea first, fought in the correspondence columns of Il corriere della sera, Puccini steamed ahead, completing La Bohème for performance in Turin in February 1896. By the time Leoncavallo's version received its premiere in Venice the following year, the battle was lost. Though his opera was acclaimed, and had a following for a decade or so, it eventually disappeared from sight.

To a modern audience, the idea that we might be persuaded to try an alternative to one of the world's best-loved operas is like being asked to sing your favourite hymn to a different tune: jolly interesting thank you but not the same. Nevertheless ENO, spurred on by the excuse of an Italian season, has taken a bold initiative and staged Leoncavallo's version, not seen in London since the UK premiere in 1970.

Anyone interested in opera should take this rare chance if only to understand more clearly what makes a great opera. This is not one. The libretto, by the composer, inevitably takes a slightly different slant from Giacosa and Illica's for Puccini. The on-off affair between Musetta and Marcello dominates, with Mimi a far slighter character, despite a couple of winning arias. When she dies, the music drums up a volley of passionate emotions but we remain detached since we know so little of her.

The first two acts are full of bustle and rapid dialogue (often in Leoncavallo's singular nine-syllable verse lines), culminating in one of those louche, demi-monde parties in which people wear monocles and silly wigs and carry dolls or dogs.

Cross dressing is de rigueur and strange things are done with phallic pencils. Little happens dramatically. In the second half, and this is indeed an opera of two halves, the music suddenly opens a flood-gate. Lyrical, almost Wagnerian emotion pours forth and you begin to understand why, in its early days, the opera was admired. Tim Albery, directing, put as much energy as he could in to bringing the work to life, as did Mark Shanahan, conducting.

The singers, drawn chiefly from the ENO company, coped well if sometimes untidily with Leoncavallo's ensembles. Christine Rice was a warm-voiced, glamorous Musetta, with Sandra Ford pert and fragile as Mimi. Paul Whelan, a bearded giant whose contract evidently obliges him to strip to his loin-cloth (as Jesus in St John Passion) or star-spangled underpants (here, as Schaunard), could grace any stage. Fortunately he can sing, too. Stefanos Lazaridis's severe grey set again looked handsome, with lighting by Jean Kalman and dazzling costumes by Jon Morrell, but despite opaque displacements of the chorus much of the gantry work became irrelevant.

Sticking to Puccini, Glyndebourne Touring Opera has rustled up the sharpest, spikiest Bohème you could hope to find, sung and played with zest and finesse. The young cast is superb. David McVicar's production strips the story bare, revealing its rawness and vitality. Sentiment is replaced by shocking credibility. The cocaine-snorting scene (duration: less than one minute) provoked advance publicity even though it's now quite passé to do drugs on stage at the opera.

Rodolfo the poet is played by Alfred Boe as a studious cool-guy scarcely out of his teens. This is a favourite role of Pavarotti, whose acting style might best be described as discreet. Boe has a light, pure voice and acts convincingly, which gives the part startling impact. Michael Vale's set is a cleverly revolving apartment of slovenly, grim modernity, with seedy kitchen units and unwashed utensils, more Hackney loft than Latin Quarter. A walkway, suggesting a fire escape, provides another lever for the action. Yvonne Patrick, standing in at short notice as Musetta sang with feisty energy and tenderness. Mimi was the stunning Italian soprano Simona Todaro, who brought to the role a touching, self-searching modesty rather than the usual easy pathos.

Louis Langree conducted a fervent account, played with spirit and enthusiasm by the GTO orchestra. Glyndebourne Rovers had the better team but the result of this virtual centenary rematch was a foregone conclusion: three nil to Puccini. If you've always wanted an alibi to visit Milton Keynes (Plymouth, Oxford, Stoke-on-Trent or, this week, Norwich) you'll never find a better one.

fields.headline: Off the wall
fields.standfirst: Buildings and trees in Soho Square are the backdrop for Tony Oursler's startling show
fields.trailText: The Influence Machine Soho Square London W1, until 12 November, 6.30-8.30pm.
fields.body:
The Influence Machine Soho Square London W1, until 12 November, 6.30-8.30pm

Communications technology has always been haunted by the idea of ghosts in the machine. Within a few years of the invention of Morse code in 1836, people were claiming that they had heard tap, tap, tapping from beyond the grave, and the Spiritualist movement was born. With the advent of radio came the idea of Electronic Voice Projection, disciples of which tuned in to obscure channels in order to interpret as infernal messages the crackle of distant voices. In more recent times, spiritualists (and schizophrenics) have seen signals from the other side on their TV screens; and now the rambling text codes of computer hard drives are being scoured in the belief that they might contain the passwords to the chat rooms of the recently deceased.

Tony Oursler, who came of age with Californian video artists such as Mike Kelly in the 1970s, has made these parallel worlds of mediums and the media his study and his obsession. In the past he has toyed with ideas of the uncanny, producing a series of rag puppets on to which he has projected human faces and looping lip-synched voices, unsettling mannikins for a televisual culture (one of which can currently be seen monologuing animatedly in the Hayward Gallery's Spectacular Bodies show). For The Influence Machine - staged with the help of Beck's Artangel, who first took Rachel Whiteread's spectral inside-out House into the East End - he expands those ideas to fill a space near where many of them took root.

In a room above Bar Italia, in Soho's Frith Street John Logie Baird first made real life (in the form of a ventriloquist's dummy) appear on a TV screen. Baird (along with his dummy) is among the guiding forces behind Oursler's disconcerting, magical projections in Soho Square just up the road. Each evening, Oursler uses the windswept trees in the little park in the centre of the square, and the facades of the buildings that surround it, to conjure something like the authentic spirit worlds of the information age, and to offer a curious commentary on the vicarious mindset of Baird's making.

In a series of connected visual stunts, vast contorting faces are beamed on to the shifting skeletons of trees to harangue you, in Oursler's dislocating poetry, about how 'there is another woman in my life, and her name is television'. Spooky computer-generated voices whisper transcripts from archived 'spirit voices' from under the eaves of the gazebo at the square's centre; text spat from Intel insides scrolled up and down one sycamore, the digitally mediated voice of the undead ('I am the spirit side manager of the team and was once in a popular rock and roll group...'); on another, a balding head 15 feet high, banged itself repeatedly against the tree trunk like a trapped naiad; and on the wall of the former hospital next to the Twentieth Century Fox building a five-storey clenched fist knock, knocked for admittance to the underworld.

The soundtrack to this intriguing, and sometimes hypnotic video tableau - what Oursler is apt to call a 'psycho landscape' - was provided by a recording of a glass harmonica, an instrument invented in the 1700s, which involved a series of glass bowls that were made to resonate when rubbed with a finger (the bowls of the original instrument were made of lead, which poisoned its virtuosos, sending them insane). The glass harmonica is one element of an erudite homage to Gaspar Robertson - a typical figure in Oursler's arcane hinterland - a necromancer and showman, who established, in 1763, the first permanent moving image theatre in a crypt in Paris, and who used the harmonica to unnerve his audience as it watched his phantasmagoria. Another is the woman's face that is projected on to smoke and which provides - like a disembodied Beckett voice - an authorial commentary on the eerie and repetitive proceedings. As this face materialises and dematerialises its voice offers a potted history of moving pictures and their psychological effect.

You can see why Oursler might be attracted to the idea of Gaspar Robertson's subterranean pyrotechnics. There is in his own project a similar ambitious sense of spectacle and mystery, and an infectious kind of home-made hucksterism. And at times, wandering in the square, you may have the strong sense of being stranded at a postmodern bonfire party, complete with desperate park keepers telling you not to step on the flower borders, Oursler's sometimes baffling show at the very least meets the age-old challenge laid down by the children's programme: 'why don't you switch off your television set and do something far more interesting instead.

fields.headline: Careful with that axe, Pete
fields.standfirst: The Who still have what it takes - Townshend
fields.trailText: The Who
fields.body:
The Who Manchester Evening News Arena

Of course I knew The Who were old - the three original members having a combined age of 166 and all that - but it still comes as a shock to see a balding, black-suited, stoop-shouldered man with the sombre visage of a pallbearer attacking his guitar with such aggression. The look on Pete Townshend's face for the first few minutes of Thursday night's triumphant gig in Manchester is really quite disturbing - in a way that it wasn't when he was 25. It's the facade of serene respectability that makes Townshend's clenched jaw and frenzied windmilling arm seem more than an old rock star's stage tricks. You can practically see the demons seeping smokily from this fingertips.

The Who, for me, are still several rungs below the truly great rock acts - The Beatles, Dylan, The Stones, The Clash, Bowie, Springsteen - not least because their albums (with the exception of Who's Next) don't stand the test of time. But as a live act, they are up there with the best. You can certainly see why America has embraced them so fervently in their autumnal years. And, professional and energetic as they are, the band's appeal has nothing to do with the supernaturally fresh-faced, full-voiced Roger Daltrey or the white-bearded, supple-fingered John Entwistle, nor the more recent additions - keyboard maestro John 'Rabbit' Bundrick, and Zac Starkey doing a credible impersonation of Keith Moon. It's all about Townshend.

I've been reading his internet diaries recently and it's complex, fascinating stuff - pretentious and self-important at times, but bristling with an intelligence that I suspect you wouldn't find in many rock stars' journals. On 5 October, for instance, he tackled the age question. 'Although there is perhaps nothing so ridiculous as this ageing man endlessly regurgitating the passion of his youth, repeating vengeful accusations against the weary old man I myself rapidly become - there is nothing more painful than to be made suddenly aware that the awful secret of growing old (that the young can never, should never, understand) is that one day the old grow young... I am conscious that I am behaving more like someone who is young than I did when I was really young.'

In other words, he is still talking 'bout his generation - and in a tone that is, unusually, neither apologetic nor smug. The fact that he didn't die before he got old does not invalidate the rebel rhetoric of 'My Generation'; rather, it gives the song another layer of meaning. Whereas Keith Richards more and more resembles some languid old bluesman, fossilised in his coolness, Townshend is visibly wiser and happier, but with the same core of volatility that sparked those three-minute mod anthems. When he tells the audience, many of whom are, like me, half his age, 'Please, please, do take care of yourselves - because every one of you is precious', it doesn't sound like sentimental flannel, but a sincere, paternal retraction of the nihilism of his youth.

Weird as it may sound, this is perhaps the best way to experience The Who. With The Stones, fun as their live shows are, you would always rather listen to Beggars Banquet or Let It Bleed. With The Who, that doesn't apply. The 'greatest hits live' is as good as it gets. And even for someone of a younger generation, Townshend strikes me as having more to say about life than most of 'our' pop spokespeople. Listen to The Who's 'My Generation' next to Limp Bizkit's song of the same name, and then tell me youth is innately more vigorous than middle age.

For all the explosive versions of old hits, all the show-off solos, the night's freshest moment is a tender reworking of 'The Kids Are Alright', dedicated to Townshend's own children. The NME may have taunted him for this heresy, but that's just blinkered, childless youth for you. Why don't he just f-f-f-fade away? Because people still dig what he's got to s-s-s-say.

webTitle: Theatre review: Taking the trough with the smooth

fields.headline: Taking the trough with the smooth
fields.standfirst: Wild as ever, Complicité put a pig in the dock
fields.trailText:
Light Almeida London N1

A Doll's House Ambassadors London WC2

Road to Heaven Lyric, Hammersmith London W6
fields.body:
Light Almeida London N1

A Doll's House Ambassadors London WC2

Road to Heaven Lyric, Hammersmith London W6

What makes Complicite the most stimulating theatre company in Britain today? It's not simply that they animate parts of the stage - and of the actors there - that most companies don't reach. Their fluid, anti-naturalistic style lets them chart territory which is usually dramatic desert. They're at home with the abstract, the speculative, the wild and the weird.

All this was true of the illuminating Mnemonic, which next year arrives at the National, from where movement theatre has been culpably absent. And it's true of the rich, brooding Light, though at the moment (Complicite's productions are always evolving) this contains indigestible lumps.

Complicite's artistic director, Simon McBurney and Matthew Broughton, have adapted Light from a novel by the Swedish writer Torgny Lindgren, one of whose books was filmed as Elvira Madigan.

Lindgren's fable was prompted by a mixture of the bygone and the contemporary; by a village that rose from the ravages of plague, by the deaths of friends from Aids, and by medieval trials of animals.

In Complicite's production, a grinning chat-show host introduces a group of villagers who, reduced to a handful by rabbit-borne disease, slide into anarchy. The white-suited compere gloatingly circles characters in dung-coloured costumes: one is toothless; one buggers his cow; one escapes terror by going into a trance. He circles them until they eject him. This is, among other things, a piece about the importance of telling your own story.

There's a huge amount going on. Those animal trials, for instance. In true Complicite style, a major contributor to the action is a giant boar - magnificently played by Joseph Alessi as a steaming beast, who dominates the front of the stage, as he strains at his leash and rears up waving his trotters, long animal bones strapped to the actor's mud-spattered arms. This is a pig which is solemnly condemned to hang for eating a baby; a pig with a biography, a pig which sometimes looks like a bald, obliging baby, sometimes resembles a BNP thug, and which becomes a dangling lump.

This story alone would be enough for most companies. But here it's intertwined with a larger debate about ways of coping with disaster: there are those who thrive on uncertainty and those who long for order; the play, which continually teases with the possibility that nothing it presents is true, opposes happy scavenger and troubled seeker after justice, but doesn't take sides.

There are episodes in Light which aren't clear, and others which are plonkingly explained. But its inventive visualisation is a marvel. Twitching rabbits turn into hats in the wink of a magi cian's, or a butcher's, eye. A fighting couple are frozen in silent, perpetual pursuit. Hooded figures tweak eerie but appealing puppets, with the blackened limbs of mummies and the wide faces and huge eyes of ET; in doing so, they act out the narrator's manipulation of the story.

As the curtain goes up on Polly Teale's Shared Experience production of A Doll's House, Anne-Marie Duff's arm waves through the window of a doll's house. In the closing moments, as she prepares to leave her husband and children, Duff unlatches a massive hook; the walls of her own house swing out - like those of a doll's house - on to a world of snow.

The bold expressionism of Teale's direction and Angela Davies's design spells out Ibsen's shadows and snares. The Helmers' house is wanly lit; the walls are cracked; patches are rubbed bare; dead leaves blow across the floor. A sharp angle, against which Nora lolls like a broken marionette, divides the main room from a small chamber, in which trusty friends sit knitting, like tricoteuses beside the guillotine. Nora's fears and regrets assume palpable form: her tormenting debt-collector looms over her, or slumps in a corner; her dead father stalks the stage.

This explicitness has one bad result: it causes some actors (the men - though not Pip Donaghy's Dr Rank) to be mouthy and over-emphatic. But it supplies an electrifying sense of danger. And it fuels Anne-Marie Duff's terrific performance, which swoops from giddy eagerness to washed-out determination; in the course of the evening her voice drops from reedy immaturity to adult dismay.

For a few glorious days the Young@Hearts chorus from Massachusetts came to London - courtesy of LIFT - and took the audience with them on their Road to Heaven. The idea for their show is, like all brilliant ideas, simple. Like most brilliant ideas, it begins by sounding barmy, and ends by seeming essential.

A group in their seventies and eighties performs pop songs. Not the songs of their youth - there are no quavering ballads - but the songs of subsequent generations. And not just the Beatles but the Stones; not just Dylan but Led Zeppelin. And the Clash. Not rocking-chair, but rock'n'roll.

Picture-book - and show-biz - versions of old age are exploded. Forget roguish twinkles and apple-cheeks; forget 'indomitable' or 'crochety'. Against a design that suggests both hospital and asylum, three cowboys in ponyskin and fluorescent green chaps belt out 'Ghost Riders in the Sky'. 'Diamonds are a girl's best friend' is performed by a drag queen batting barbed-wire eyelashes. With tutu and wobbly wand, a white-haired woman knowingly lisps: 'Nobody loves a fairy when she's 80'; 'We do,' shouted a voice on the first night.

Every song takes on a different tinge: why have we assumed they're written for the young? Yelled by Jagger, 'Satisfaction' is a boast; it's rendered here as a considered, ferocious complaint. 'I didn't know what time it was' - usually a melancholy romance - becomes disturbing when delivered, with dry precision by a clever, elderly woman. This extraordinary, funny and stirring show must return. And surely London should be treated to the chorus's 'Louis Lou I', a retelling of the French Revolution through the songs of Sinatra.

fields.headline: Never mind the hollyhocks...
fields.standfirst: The National Gallery's new collection of impressionists is big on cute dogs and flowers, but short on meaning
fields.trailText: Impression National Gallery, WC2, until 28 January 2001.
fields.body:
Impression National Gallery, WC2, until 28 January 2001

Impressionsism may have become a mode of seeing, but it began as a way of life. Walter Pater, in the inflammatory conclusion to his 1873 study of the Renaissance, enjoined his readers not to form habits, which turn us into conventional, drearily moral creatures. Loosen reality, he urged; surrender to your senses; let the solid, workaday world dissipate into a hazy penumbra of impressions. This was a prescription for living hedonistically, relishing moments and acknowledging the supreme unimportance of being earnest.

The National Gallery's new show, Impression, documents the pictorial style while ignoring the ethical imperatives behind it. The exhibition's subtitle is 'Painting Quickly in France, 1860-1890', and it invites us to concentrate on the breezy, gestural antics of brushwork rather than bothering about what the pictures mean. The curator, Richard R. Brettell, a Texan academic, likens this myopic gaze to 'the radically reductive methods of what literary historians called "the New Criticism"'.

The New Criticism hasn't been new, alas, since the 1950s, when it was the fashion to analyse the verbal involutions of a poem without asking whether the words had anything to say. The approach, as Brettell admits, was reductive. It's therefore odd that he thinks it worth applying this discredited technique to visual art. But universities set a premium on such jargon, and if you can't come up with a genuinely new idea, you may as well resuscitate an old one.

Brettell's thesis requires us to study the slapdash energy of the painters displayed - the fuzzy, fluent brush-strokes of Pissarro, Berthe Morisot's zigzags of pigment, the showers of liq uid paint with which Renoir dotted his canvases, the wet-in-wet dabblings of Sisley.

There is a useful point to this, since the impressionists proudly advertised their facility, disregarding the laboured detail and impervious finish prized by their predecessors. Ruskin promised that his illustrations to The Stones of Venice would have an 'almost servile veracity'; he was scandalised by Whistler who, like the impressionists, transcribed the visual world so hazily and hastily. According to Ruskin, Whistler's nocturnes had no value as art because they were painted so quickly. Ruskin studies Venice with slavish verisimilitude; the Venice of Renoir, on view at the National Gallery, is a humid, shimmering mirage.

The difference, however, goes beyond technique. Ruskin's veracity was pious. His description of St Mark's cathedral concludes by noticing that 'Christ and His angels' surmount the domes. For Renoir, the great church is no longer a testament to faith. Molten in the heat, it deliquesces; the impression is almost an illusion. Brettell's exclusive attention to the 'viscous strokes of white, beige, gray and brown' prevents him from seeing what Renoir has done to a cathedral and the religion it once upheld.

The argument about speed of execution is extended implausibly to artists who should not be looked at in the fickle, fluttery way Impression proposes. Manet, for instance, appears here as an honorary impressionist, which he is emphatically not. His technique was painstaking because the world of work and political action he depicted was one in which pains had to be taken. His view of the Grand Canal in Venice is not a bombardment of sun spots, like Renoir's San Marco. He concentrates on the city inhab ited by artisans: a gondola resembles a foreshortened barge and the buildings behind it are a cliff of tenements. Manet can only be made to fit by exhibiting a negligent sketch for his painting of the bar at the Folies-Bergère, which is better in its finished state, or a murky and imprecise copy of Delacroix.

Manet's Woman Reading , borrowed from Chicago, has an importance beyond its sketchy surface. Brettell counts the 'no more than 20 separate strokes of paint' that conjure up her face, but fails to notice that this painting about the act of reading itself ought to be read. At a café table with a glass of beer beside her, the woman has snatched a magazine from the rack and is skimming it. Here is Manet's announcement that art should aspire to the condition of journalism, not (as the mid-nineteenth century's epic painters intended) to that of history. But for Brettell, sprucing up his jargon, the scene is merely one more 'performative project', in which the brush strokes are twinkle-toed ballerinas.

The other artist unconvincingly presented as a gestural performer is Van Gogh. Impression concludes by assembling a group of his paintings under the heading 'The Post Impression', a term as desperately vacuous as postmodern. Brettell expatiates on the 'brutal' and 'strongly linear' brush strokes applied by Van Gogh to a pair of shoes, without considering the significance of those dirty, dented, careworn boots, which are an antidote to the volatile ballet slippers worn by the dancers of Degas.

Van Gogh's work repudiates the casualness which Impression extols. The vortex of swirls in his Entrance to a Quarry looks maniacal, and in Trunks of Trees with Ivy , painted just outside the gates of the hospital where he was being treated for epilepsy, the ivy has the trees in a stranglehold, while the surface of the canvas is ridged with pigment as prickly as a security fence of barbed wire.

The exhibition is safer when confining itself to the suburban picnic sites favoured by these painters - the Isle of Wight, for instance, described by Berthe Morisot as 'the prettiest place for painting'. This cult of prettiness presumably explains the inclusion of Renoir's gooey portrait of a King Charles spaniel. Having drawn attention to the fawning creature's 'liquid eyes', Brettell admits that the picture cannot be 'regarded as a serious work of art'. Quite so, but in that case what's it doing here? I suppose there are demographic reasons, since people who like the impressionists must be fond of cute, sycophantic dogs.

For keen gardeners, there are lots of flowers: roses by Renoir, hollyhocks by Morisot. Impression hopes to beguile the public it targets until Cruft's and the Chelsea Flower Show come round.

At its worst, the exhibition confirms the culinary reputation of Monet, Renoir and their colleagues. Brettell treats pictures as if they were edible, savouring the 'buttery, pale-yellow paint' in a Renoir view of the Grand Canal. His taste buds, rather than his critical taste, have persuaded him to borrow Monet's worthless por trait of the Alsatian chef, Père Paul, whose hedge of whiskers make me wonder how many stray hairs and flakes of dandruff found their way into his sauces.

Pater, recommending an impressionistic surrender to sensation, had more than this sickly calorific diet of pigment in mind. These painters were seditious, shocking, recklessly experimental. Monet's Gare St Lazare represented a cathedral for an age whose religion was science: the railway station is a nave of iron and glass, and the Holy Ghost is a vaporous cloud of steam. Brettell notices only the painting's 'gusto', which is another unhelpful word for taste. This approach is trivially rather than radically reductive. Impression , I'm afraid, left me unimpressed.

 Laura Cumming is on holiday

fields.headline: Ivory coasts to another triumph
fields.trailText:
The Golden Bowl (126 mins , 12) Directed by James Ivory; starring Nick Nolte, Uma Thurman, Kate Beckinsale, Jeremy Northam
Grey Owl (118 mins, PG) Directed by Richard Attenborough; starring Pierce Brosnan, Annie Galipeau
Purely Belter (97 mins, 15) Directed by Mark Herman; starring Chris Beattie, Greg McLane, Tim Healy, Kevin Whately
Loser (95 mins, 12) Directed by Amy Heckerling; starring Jason Biggs, Mena Suvari, Greg Kinnear
fields.body:
The Golden Bowl (126 mins , 12) Directed by James Ivory; starring Nick Nolte, Uma Thurman, Kate Beckinsale, Jeremy Northam
Grey Owl (118 mins, PG) Directed by Richard Attenborough; starring Pierce Brosnan, Annie Galipeau
Purely Belter (97 mins, 15) Directed by Mark Herman; starring Chris Beattie, Greg McLane, Tim Healy, Kevin Whately
Loser (95 mins, 12) Directed by Amy Heckerling; starring Jason Biggs, Mena Suvari, Greg Kinnear

Henry James recovered from the depression that followed his failure to achieve popular success as a playwright in the 1890s, and in the first five years of the next century wrote three final masterpieces - The Wings of the Dove, The Ambassadors and The Golden Bowl. As his admirer Graham Greene remarked: 'He was never so much of a dramatist as when he had ceased to have theatrical ambitions'.

The team of writer Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, producer Ishmail Merchant and directory James Ivory, who previously adapted The Europeans and The Bostonians, again demonstrate with their version of The Golden Bowl how effective James can be on the screen. It's their best work since The Remains of the Day, though altogether more in thrall to the country house and less socially critical.

Stripped of James's ornate, periphrastic late style, a simple, intriguing story remains of an unhealthily close father and daughter, the widowed American billionaire, Adam Verver (Nick Nolte), and his only child, Maggie (Kate Beckinsale), marrying two sophisticated fortune hunters - Maggie's beautiful but penniless schoolfriend, Charlotte (Uma Thurman), and the handsome, impecunious Italian aristocrat, Prince Amerigo (Jeremy Northam).

Unbeknown to the Ververs, Charlotte and the prince are former lovers, a relationship they subsequently resume until they surrender to power, convention and destiny. The moral is pointed in the eponymous Byzantine gilded bowl, a beautiful object with a hidden flaw that renders it worthless in the eyes of some.

(The film refrains from using the prince's description of the dealer who sold it as 'the little swindling Jew', an example of what used to be called 'gentlemanly anti-Semitism.')

The names spell out the allegory - Amerigo, the tired European who discovered America but stayed at home to luxuriate in tradition; Adam, the American innocent who virtually owns an industrial metropolis called American City that he intends to civilise by creating a grand museum in the Roman style full of European art treasures.

The film lacks the novel's mystery and complexity, though some of the hollowness derives from James's own confusion and ignorance. But it's sumptuously staged and has an outstanding performance from Nick Nolte, who perfectly combines the power and sensitivity that James attributed to his idealised American plutocrat.

Jeremy Northam's prince, however, probably because of the elaborate Italian accent, seems more of a suave conman than an honest, agonising aristocrat.

Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (with whom, the young Henry James observed: 'I lately spent a pleasant evening and found him bland and mildly anecdotal') famously wrote that

'Lives of great men all remind us
We can make our lives sublime,
And, departing, leave behind us
Footprints on the sands of time.'

That uplifting sentiment might stand as an epigraph to the hero-worshipping movies of Richard Attenborough. But after Churchill, Gandhi, Biko, Chaplin and Hemingway, the latest addition to the Attenborough pantheon, the eponymous Grey Owl, hasn't left much in the way of a footprint. And it will be for James Bond, not his portrait of this Canadian conservationist, that Pierce Brosnan's footprints will be stamped in the foyer of Grauman's Chinese Theatre on Sunset Boulevard.

This warm-hearted labour of love tells the story of the lower-middle-class Englishman, Archie Belaney, steeped from childhood in wilderness lore, who emigrated to Canada as a teenager, reinvented himself as the Indian Grey Owl, and in the 1930s became a best-selling author and lecturer on environmental matters, and a guest at Buckingham Palace.

His true identity wasn't revealed until after his death in 1938.

There's a fascinating story here, but it is sentimentalised and Disneyfied in William Nicholson's screenplay which concentrates on the crucial influence on Archie of a tiresome déracinée Mohawk beauty called Pony (Annie Galipeau). She gets him to instruct her in 'the old ways' and ends up converting him from trapping to conservation. The best sequence is his return to Hastings to visit the elderly aunts (Stephanie Cole, Renée Asherson) who reared him. The claims made for his significance seemed greatly exaggerated.

Mark Herman's Purely Belter is The Likely Lads 30 years on. But the successors to the hopeful Tyneside boys of the 1960s are a hopeless pair of permanently truanting teenagers, the smart, aggressive Gerry (Chris Beatty), and the dim, compliant Sewell (Greg McClane). They've grown up in a culture of permanent unemployment, of broken families, runaway, drug-addicted sisters, feckless chain-smoking mothers, drunken, abusive fathers, indifferent teachers, ineffectual social workers. Ironically offering them moral support is Antony Gormley's 'Angel of the North'.

As in Brassed Off, Herman lays it on with a trowel. The only thing that will gain Gerry and Sewell the respect they seek is the wherewithal (£1,000) to buy season tickets to see Newcastle Utd, and they set about raising it by begging, shoplifting, burglary and bank-robbery. For this last, bungled crime they're sentenced to 200 hours' community service - they should, of course, have been sentenced to six months at the Royal Ballet School.

Purely Belter is a lively, coarse, often very funny film with a brief appearance by Alan Shearer as himself (the lads steal his sportscar for a joyride in the country) and no concessions over matters of dialect (the title is Geordie for 'as good as it gets').

This kind of state-of-the-nation movie has been around since the 1980s and used to be called 'The Cinema of Thatcher's Britain'. Which suggests that as far as moviemakers are concerned, the difference between Blair's Britain and Thatcher's is the same as the traditional distinction between capitalism and communism - under one system man exploits man; under the other, it's the other way around.

Amy Heckerling's last movie, Clueless , was an enjoyable updating of Jane Austen's Emma to present-day Los Angeles. Her moderately entertaining new picture, Loser, is virtually a reworking of Wilder's The Apartment at a New York university.

In this case, Paul, a small-town scholarship lad (Jason Biggs), is ill-treated by his rich, idle contemporaries until they need his off-campus room to throw orgiastic parties.

The girl he secretly loves (Mena Suvari from American Beauty ) is the mistress of a smug English teacher (Greg Kinnear) and when she's left near death at one of the rich kids' parties, Paul cares for her, though she briefly returns to the cynic who exploits her. This was a sharper brew when made with a Lemmon.
fields.bodyText: The Golden Bowl (126 mins , 12) Directed by James Ivory; starring Nick Nolte, Uma Thurman, Kate Beckinsale, Jeremy Northam Grey Owl (118 mins, PG) Directed by Richard Attenborough; starring Pierce Brosnan, Annie Galipeau Purely Belter (97 mins, 15) Directed by Mark Herman; starring Chris Beattie, Greg McLane, Tim Healy, Kevin Whately Loser (95 mins, 12) Directed by Amy Heckerling; starring Jason Biggs, Mena Suvari, Greg Kinnear Henry James recovered from the depression that followed his failure to achieve popular success as a playwright in the 1890s, and in the first five years of the next century wrote three final masterpieces - The Wings of the Dove, The Ambassadors and The Golden Bowl. As his admirer Graham Greene remarked: 'He was never so much of a dramatist as when he had ceased to have theatrical ambitions'. The team of writer Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, producer Ishmail Merchant and directory James Ivory, who previously adapted The Europeans and The Bostonians, again demonstrate with their version of The Golden Bowl how effective James can be on the screen. It's their best work since The Remains of the Day, though altogether more in thrall to the country house and less socially critical. Stripped of James's ornate, periphrastic late style, a simple, intriguing story remains of an unhealthily close father and daughter, the widowed American billionaire, Adam Verver (Nick Nolte), and his only child, Maggie (Kate Beckinsale), marrying two sophisticated fortune hunters - Maggie's beautiful but penniless schoolfriend, Charlotte (Uma Thurman), and the handsome, impecunious Italian aristocrat, Prince Amerigo (Jeremy Northam). Unbeknown to the Ververs, Charlotte and the prince are former lovers, a relationship they subsequently resume until they surrender to power, convention and destiny. The moral is pointed in the eponymous Byzantine gilded bowl, a beautiful object with a hidden flaw that renders it worthless in the eyes of some. (The film refrains from using the prince's description of the dealer who sold it as 'the little swindling Jew', an example of what used to be called 'gentlemanly anti-Semitism.') The names spell out the allegory - Amerigo, the tired European who discovered America but stayed at home to luxuriate in tradition; Adam, the American innocent who virtually owns an industrial metropolis called American City that he intends to civilise by creating a grand museum in the Roman style full of European art treasures. The film lacks the novel's mystery and complexity, though some of the hollowness derives from James's own confusion and ignorance. But it's sumptuously staged and has an outstanding performance from Nick Nolte, who perfectly combines the power and sensitivity that James attributed to his idealised American plutocrat. Jeremy Northam's prince, however, probably because of the elaborate Italian accent, seems more of a suave conman than an honest, agonising aristocrat. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (with whom, the young Henry James observed: 'I lately spent a pleasant evening and found him bland and mildly anecdotal') famously wrote that 'Lives of great men all remind us We can make our lives sublime, And, departing, leave behind us Footprints on the sands of time.' That uplifting sentiment might stand as an epigraph to the hero-worshipping movies of Richard Attenborough. But after Churchill, Gandhi, Biko, Chaplin and Hemingway, the latest addition to the Attenborough pantheon, the eponymous Grey Owl, hasn't left much in the way of a footprint. And it will be for James Bond, not his portrait of this Canadian conservationist, that Pierce Brosnan's footprints will be stamped in the foyer of Grauman's Chinese Theatre on Sunset Boulevard. This warm-hearted labour of love tells the story of the lower-middle-class Englishman, Archie Belaney, steeped from childhood in wilderness lore, who emigrated to Canada as a teenager, reinvented himself as the Indian Grey Owl, and in the 1930s became a best-selling author and lecturer on environmental matters, and a guest at Buckingham Palace. His true identity wasn't revealed until after his death in 1938. There's a fascinating story here, but it is sentimentalised and Disneyfied in William Nicholson's screenplay which concentrates on the crucial influence on Archie of a tiresome déracinée Mohawk beauty called Pony (Annie Galipeau). She gets him to instruct her in 'the old ways' and ends up converting him from trapping to conservation. The best sequence is his return to Hastings to visit the elderly aunts (Stephanie Cole, Renée Asherson) who reared him. The claims made for his significance seemed greatly exaggerated. Mark Herman's Purely Belter is The Likely Lads 30 years on. But the successors to the hopeful Tyneside boys of the 1960s are a hopeless pair of permanently truanting teenagers, the smart, aggressive Gerry (Chris Beatty), and the dim, compliant Sewell (Greg McClane). They've grown up in a culture of permanent unemployment, of broken families, runaway, drug-addicted sisters, feckless chain-smoking mothers, drunken, abusive fathers, indifferent teachers, ineffectual social workers. Ironically offering them moral support is Antony Gormley's 'Angel of the North'. As in Brassed Off, Herman lays it on with a trowel. The only thing that will gain Gerry and Sewell the respect they seek is the wherewithal (£1,000) to buy season tickets to see Newcastle Utd, and they set about raising it by begging, shoplifting, burglary and bank-robbery. For this last, bungled crime they're sentenced to 200 hours' community service - they should, of course, have been sentenced to six months at the Royal Ballet School. Purely Belter is a lively, coarse, often very funny film with a brief appearance by Alan Shearer as himself (the lads steal his sportscar for a joyride in the country) and no concessions over matters of dialect (the title is Geordie for 'as good as it gets'). This kind of state-of-the-nation movie has been around since the 1980s and used to be called 'The Cinema of Thatcher's Britain'. Which suggests that as far as moviemakers are concerned, the difference between Blair's Britain and Thatcher's is the same as the traditional distinction between capitalism and communism - under one system man exploits man; under the other, it's the other way around. Amy Heckerling's last movie, Clueless , was an enjoyable updating of Jane Austen's Emma to present-day Los Angeles. Her moderately entertaining new picture, Loser, is virtually a reworking of Wilder's The Apartment at a New York university. In this case, Paul, a small-town scholarship lad (Jason Biggs), is ill-treated by his rich, idle contemporaries until they need his off-campus room to throw orgiastic parties. The girl he secretly loves (Mena Suvari from American Beauty ) is the mistress of a smug English teacher (Greg Kinnear) and when she's left near death at one of the rich kids' parties, Paul cares for her, though she briefly returns to the cynic who exploits her. webTitle: Theatre: What have they done to our Monty?

fields.headline: What have they done to our Monty?
fields.standfirst: Broadway asset-strippers have replaced Sheffield with Buffalo, NY. What, no Hot Chocolate?  Vanessa Thorpe  reports
fields.trailText: Broadway asset-strippers have replaced Sheffield with Buffalo, NY. What, no Hot Chocolate? Vanessa Thorpe reports.
fields.body:
Our story begins in Buffalo, in New York State's declining 'rust belt'. Six former steel mill workers, out of shape and out of work, decide to take their lives in hand. They may not have jobs, but they are, after all, still men. And women will always need men. Shouldn't they be making the most of their remaining visible assets?

Does the premise sound familiar? Replace the shores of Lake Erie with the foothills of the Pennines, the defunct steel mills of Buffalo with the defunct steel mills of Sheffield, and we have The Full Monty .

In Britain we have known for a while how strongly Americans felt about the original film - it took $45 million at the box office. But we didn't realise quite how possessive they had become.

Now, just a week after the opening of The Full Monty: the musical, the gritty northern fable is halfway to being appropriated as part of the American Dream. It is already the hottest- selling ticket on Broadway and one day it may even earn the rare accolade of breaking even. The critics have been positive. Ben Brantley in the New York Times called it 'that rare aggressive crowd-pleaser that you don't have to apologise for liking'. To the Daily News it was 'fresh, bouncy and downright delightful'.

'There was an awful long line waiting for seats today,' said a proud member of the production team on Friday.

But there is one key person in The Full Monty saga who has not been queuing for a ticket: the British screenwriter, Simon Beaufoy. Only a few of Beaufoy's original lines remain in the musical and he no longer regards it as his story.

'He feels it is nothing to do with him now and he has no plans to go to see it,' Beaufoy's agent, Rod Hall, told The Observer last week. Beaufoy was not even invited to the first night.

The book for the new musical has been almost entirely rewritten by Terrence McNally, the playwright recently embroiled in religious controversy after his play Corpus Christi, about a gay Christ figure, was staged in New York and London. McNally, who also wrote the book for Kiss of the Spiderwoman , has had no contact with Beaufoy and has only seen the film once.

So how did America manage to hi-jack this British hit? On the strength of the film, two influential showbusiness executives gave up their day jobs in order to bring a musical treatment of the story to the stage. One of them was Lindsay Law, former president of 20th Century Fox's Searchlight division, the company who released the original Monty.

'It was a one-time-only adventure,' he says. 'Although the film was set in Sheffield, it was obvious it translated everywhere. It is the same heart and for that reason it could travel.'

At Fox, Law was in charge of around 80 film scripts at any moment. He was keen to focus on one project only and he chose The Full Monty.

Now a co-producer of the musical along with Thomas Hall, the former director of San Diego's Old Globe Theater, Law is to visit London this week to 'explore the possibility' of bringing the show to Britain. A tour of America has just been agreed, he says, and there are also plans to take it to Hamburg, Madrid, Mexico City and Sydney. But London, he knows, will be the real problem.

'We have an American musical here and it would not be at all easy to change it to a British musical, although we have utilised a British movie. Our biggest concern is Great Britain by virtue of the special affection in its heart for this story.'

Despite the fact that the producers have had no contact with the original Monty creative team, they have taken out an advertisement in the show's programme which formally thanks both Beaufoy and Umberto Pasolini, the producer of the film.

'Reviews have said how closely it sticks to the movie,' says Law. 'We do have a couple of new women characters - a jazzy accompanist and a female stripper - but the guys are true to the original guys.'

Law denies that he has simply Americanised the story to make it commercially acceptable in the States. 'Musical comedy is one of the few art forms that is original to America. We invented it and there are many more practitioners here, so it made sense for me to develop it out here. Then, of course, the team were going to be much more comfortable doing it with an American story rather than wondering all the time what those guys in Sheffield would have said.

'Even over here there are plenty who fail constantly by writing boring musicals. A lot of the stuff on Broadway is full of mugging and "large" acting. The Full Monty is true to life and as a result has a much more substantial book.'

It is a specific writing skill, Law argues, to be able to establish a character in a couple of lines and then lead him into a song. 'Terrence wrote the complete book to the show and then it was obvious some scenes were going to be better as songs.'

The show has nearly double the budget of the film, which has made around £170 million worldwide. But the talent hired to work on the musical did not look, on paper, like a team that would guarantee a hit. Take McNally. More than 2,000 catholics, Hindus and Muslims demonstrated on the streets when his play Corpus Christi came to Manhattan. He did not seem the natural choice to write for a fun, family night out.

The composer, David Yazbek, had previously written only for an obscure rock band, and Jack O'Brien, the director, has a chequered track record. His previous show, More to Love, closed after four days in 1998. Even the show's star, Patrick Wilson, arrived fresh from two critical disasters, Fascinating Rhythm and Bright Lights, Big City.

The show was initially 'workshopped' quietly with 12 actors and then staged in full in San Diego. For Law, this slow creative process was crucial. 'It was a question of listening to your show to see what you had,' he says.

What they had was a show with songs that rhymed 'carving' with 'Lee Marvin' and 'cojones' with 'testosterones'. Our heroes are a divorced father called Jerry and his chunky pal, Dave, who collaborate with four friends in a last-ditch search for cash and self-esteem. The famous dole-queue bopping scene is gone, so too is the moment when the troupe learn to dance by aping the Arsenal defence appeal for offside. Instead the gay love element in the plot has been enhanced and basketball replaces football. As in the film, the story builds to the climatic question, will they ever strip bare? And it is a question that has the audience in a nightly frenzy. 'They scream and yell, and not just at the stripping,' says Law, 'but at the humour. I was nervous about the Wednesday matinee because they were older women, but they were just as raucous.'

Some of the mass delirium induced by the show's finale is, it should be pointed out, rather whooped up by the fact that female members of the cast join the audience in the stalls. It is a revelatory theatrical moment, though, and one which underlines exactly why it was decided it might be rather ambiguous to translate the British phrase 'the full monty' into its American equivalent, 'the whole nine yards'.

 'The Full Monty': Eugene O' Neill Theatre, New York (00 1 212 239 6200), booking to 14 Jan.

fields.headline: Marilyn Manson is back. Call an exorcist!
fields.trailText: Manson may not have been responsible for the Columbine slayings, but he's guilty all right. Not just of making dreary music and wearing too much eye-liner, but of creepier excesses: raiding graveyards for human remains and a declaration in favour of George W. Bush.
fields.body:
In the summer of 1998, in the wake of the Columbine High School massacre, the NME ran a cover story in defence of goth rocker Marilyn Manson, who had been cited as the evil influence which turned a pair of teenage boys into the slayers of their fellow students. 'Not Guilty' declared the headline. Boy were they ever wrong.

Manson may not have been responsible for the Columbine slayings, but he's guilty all right. Not just of making dreary music and wearing too much eye-liner, but of creepier excesses: raiding graveyards for human remains, a fascination for prosthetic limbs, and a recent declaration in favour of George W. Bush. Anyone interested in the sordid details should check out his autobiography, The Long Road Out of Hell.

There they can also read a little, but not too much, about Manson's fascination with Satanism, whose agenda underpins almost everything that the 31-year-old musician has created. America's self-styled Moral Majority have long maintained as much, denouncing Manson as an agent of Lucifer, out to poison the minds and souls of American youth.

For once, the hardcore Christians have a point, albeit one very easily lost amid their hysterical conspiracy theories. For according to the fundamentalists, the whole of rock music is a satanic plot of which even the cuddly old Beatles are a part. This is the same crew who have successfully campaigned to have the Harry Potter books banned in several American states on account of their sinister occultism - just look at the S (for Satan) formed by the scar on Harry's forehead !

But Brian Warner - to use Manson's more mundane given name - really does preach a kind of Satanism, which oozes unpleasantly from the pus-filled imagery of his songs and artworks (scabs, ulcers, tumours and bodily disease are a constant in MM songs). His constant lampooning of Christianity and obsession with the crucifixion are one thing, and can be explained as an attack on the moral hypocrisy of the church and as a reaction against his own fundamentalist schooling (arch Satanist Aleister Crowley, likewise, was raised a Plymouth Brethren).

But beyond that come the trappings of pentagrams, planetary glyphys, and tarot trumps featuring Manson in the darkest aspect of The Hanged Man, The Magician, The Emperor and The Devil. There are sub-Nietzschean lyrics like 'the weak are there to justify the strong' (an idea lifted almost intact from Mein Kampf) .

Promoting his new album, Holy Wood (out next week), Manson even said: 'The two years since my last album have been filled with God and rappers. It's time for Death and Satan to be put in the forefront'.

Most commentators see all this merely as a combination of shock tactics and shrewd business sense, which they certainly are. But there is also an underlying philosophy of hatred, destruction, and power which is drawn from the darker side of esoteric thought, and in which there is a notable absence of compassion.

Rock music has, of course, been here before, most notably around the time that Charles Manson was becoming famous for his particular cocktail of psychedelic drugs, pop songs and mass murder. Marilyn Manson (who chose his name as a tribute to this monster) is the most dedicated of rock's modern neo- Satanists. 'Darkness and light, good and evil go hand in hand, you can't separate them,' he says. Well, yes Brian, but most of us grow up being scared of the dark; you are scared of the light. Now take your skeleton chandeliers and shove off.

fields.headline: A wild, winter wonderland
fields.standfirst: A subtle, funny, intelligent film about literature... and it stars Michael Douglas
fields.trailText: Wonder Boys (111 mins, 15) Directed by Curtis Hanson; starring Michael Douglas, Frances McDormand, Tobey Maguire, Robert Downey Jr
fields.body:
Wonder Boys (111 mins, 15) Directed by Curtis Hanson; starring Michael Douglas, Frances McDormand, Tobey Maguire, Robert Downey Jr

Curtis Hanson is one of those interesting figures who made their way into direction via movie criticism and screenwriting. But while his movies - all of them thrillers - were enjoyable enough, it took L.A. Confidential to elevate him to that currently small league of film-makers whose next film one eagerly looks forward to. We've had to wait three years for its successor, Wonder Boys, a delightful and constantly surprising film, far removed from the world of big-city crime, though there is a killing (of a dog), a theft (of a remarkable piece of memorabilia) and a fleeting glimpse of James Ellroy at a writers' conference.

Adapted by Steve Kloves (writer-director of the lively The Fabulous Baker Boys ) from Michael Chabon's funny, accurate novel of the literary life, Wonder Boys is set during a couple of overcast, winter days in Pittsburgh and centres on Grady Tripp (Michael Douglas), a critically esteemed novelist in his late forties, who teaches a creative writing workshop at a local university. Grady, the film's narrator and present in every scene, is in trouble.

He's overweight, addicted to the weed and hasn't published a book for seven years, though far from having a writer's block his problem is a manuscript of nearly 3,000 single-space pages that he can't bring to an end. Moreover, his wife has just left him (though, as he tells us, 'wives have left me before'); his old chum and editor Crabtree (Robert Downey Jr) is coming from New York to attend the university's annual 'Bookfest'; and his lover Sara (Frances McDormand), who happens to be chancellor of the university and married to Grady's boss, the head of the English department, announces her pregnancy. Not surprisingly, he's subject to anxiety attacks which leave him prostrate.

This is the stuff of tragedy and might have been unbearably painful. Two things prevent it from being so. The first is the sardonic wit that accompanies the juggling act which keeps Grady's problems from crashing to the ground around him. The second is the warmth we feel towards the shambling Grady, an honest teacher, a respecter of truth if not always of persons, a man trying to do the decent thing.

To have seen Robin Williams in this role would have been unbearable. But Douglas, like his father, never invites easy sympathy and the neurotic characters they often play scorn sentimentality and embrace losing with dignity. Easy pathos is kept at bay (or gently mocked) until the tidying up process at the end. Until then the action is driven for ward with the speed of classical farce.

There are numerous odd strands to the plot - a black guy believes that Grady has stolen his car; the head of English is obsessed with baseball memorabilia and is writing a book on Monroe and DiMaggio called The Last American Marriage; a transvestite tuba player briefly crosses Grady's path; Crabtree, Grady's reckless bisexual editor, is at the end of his tether and needs a successful book or a new author to keep his publishing job.

The central thread in the narrative skein, however, is Grady's relationship with a brilliant, deeply disturbed student, James Leer (Tobey Maguire), an inveterate liar, who transmutes the fantasies of his life into the verities of fiction. Grady and James are bound together not only as teacher and pupil and as potential literary rivals but also through a bizarre incident at a party for visiting writers at the chancellor's house. James is an obsessive film buff with an encyclopedic knowledge of popular culture and Grady shows him the black satin jacket trimmed with ermine that Marilyn Monroe wore at her 1954 marriage to Joe DiMaggio, the most closely guarded possession of the head of English. James steals this numinous garment immediately after killing the head of English's vicious dog who has attacked Grady, having intuited that his master is being cuckolded. This hilarious episode fuels the whole film, but the relationship is handled with a sensitivity reminiscent of Lionel Trilling's celebrated story Of This Time, Of That Place, about of a university professor confronted with an insane pupil.

Wonder Boys flies in the face of a dumbed-down Hollywood through literary references and jokes that depend on some passing acquaintance with the names of Carlyle, Macaulay, Hadley, Hemingway and Genet, and it touches lightly but deftly on aspects of the literary process. It's also put together with loving care by a production team that includes Dede Allen, one of the great editors in movie history, Dante Spinotti, the Italian cinematographer who lit Manhunter, Heat and L.A. fields.headline: Make yourself at home in a little bit of history
fields.standfirst: Alexander Garrett reports on the pride and pain of living in a listed building
fields.trailText: Alexander Garrett reports on the pride and pain of living in a listed building.
fields.body:
For some people it can add an extra thrill to the excitement of buying a new house. Those few words, 'listed as being of architectural or historical significance' in the estate agent's details provide the reassurance that the property in your radar sights really is something special.

But while buying a listed property may impress friends whose homes have not been similarly blessed, it means sacrificing a good deal of freedom to redecorate. In extreme cases, it can leave you at loggerheads with the so-called heritage police, and seriously out of pocket.

There are around 450,000 listed properties in England and Wales, divided into three classes. The vast majority, some 418,000, are Grade II; a further 18,000 are Grade III; and only 6,000 have a Grade I listing, which represents buildings of the greatest importance. The main reasons for listing are that a house was built by a prominent architect, or is deemed to be a good example of a particular type of craftsmanship or design. Alternatively, it may have historic value, for example by association with people or events of national importance.

In practice, any building older than 1700 is automatically listed, as are most dating from between 1700 and 1840. Relatively few buildings from the twentieth century are listed, though the numbers have increased lately, with buildings from the Sixties being added. In the broadest terms, a house which is Georgian or earlier is almost certainly listed, while Victorian is far less likely, and with an Edwardian or later house it is quite the exception.

The basic rule applying to all listed houses is that they cannot be either demolished or structurally altered without listed building consent, in addition to any planning permission that you would usually have to obtain.

For the majority whose house is Grade II, the consent will usually be given by the local planning authority, possibly after consultation with conservation groups; but with the higher grades, English Heritage is called in.

Simon Edwards, of estate agents FPD Savills in Hampstead, London, says: 'There is a popular misconception that this only affects changes you want to make to the exterior of the building. That is quite wrong, because it affects any structural alterations.' The danger, he says, is that once you have applied for consent, it can result in a raft of new restrictions.

'Suppose you want to knock through from one room to another; the planning officer comes to inspect and announces that you can't move that fireplace, or that a particular cornice must be retained.'

Curiously, he says, many buyers of listed properties don't, before buying, even obtain the actual listing which should at least give an indication of the features that are most likely to be protected. The listing may say the house has interesting ironwork, for example. There is a rotting ornamental balcony that you wanted to get rid of, but instead you find yourself having to restore it at great expense.

One of the risks of buying a listed property needing a lot of work is that you have no way of knowing how reasonable the local planning authority - or English Heritage officer - is going to be. Usually, says Simon Edwards, they will want the basic proportions of the main reception rooms to be preserved, but will be less fussy about a basement being knocked through.

However, restrictions can be severe. When a cash-starved local literary institute needed to refurbish its building, the stucco was knocked off and it was discovered that wooden lintels underneath were rotten. The institute asked to replace the lintels with concrete, which would then be hidden by the stucco, but was told that it had not only to replace them with wood, but that the wood had to be with oak of the same age as the originals.

The Department for Culture, Media and Sport, which is responsible for the listing of buildings, publishes a guide for owners, What Listing Means .

Its advice on the subject is that 'even relatively minor works, such as painting, may affect the character of a listed building, and it is therefore advisable to consult your local planning authority before starting if you are in any doubt'.

The penalty for not doing so can be harsh. Three years ago, Conservative MP Teresa Gorman and her husband were each fined £3,000 after they altered their sixteenth century Grade II-listed farmhouse in Essex without permission. They were also ordered to reverse some of the alterations, which included replacement of windows and the addition of a porch.

There are few advantages to owning a listed building to balance the restrictions. You could apply to English Heritage, which gives grants totalling around £35 million each year for the repair of important buildings. If your house is not Grade I or Grade II, though, you have little chance of success unless it is endangered in some way. There are also some grants available from local authorities.

The other concession is that alterations - but not repairs - which have been given consent, can benefit from zero-rating on VAT. However, that may be easily outweighed by requirements to use more expensive building materials as well as craftspeople.

As to the effect on the property's value: that is probably negligible, unless major modernisation is required, in which case listed status could knock a hefty sum off the price. The process of getting listed building consent can be a lengthy one and if you can't live there in the meantime, that may prove expensive in its own right.
