fields.headline: Home alone Joan
fields.standfirst: After a troubled childhood, two failed marriages and a TV career as the 'beauty with brains', Joan Bakewell faces a new challenge: being single in her sixties
fields.trailText: After a troubled childhood, two failed marriages and a TV career as the 'beauty with brains', Joan Bakewell faces a new challenge: being single in her sixties
fields.body:
When she was a child, she says, she was rather plain; not beautiful at all - a plump and pigtailed swot whose father would sit by her side in the evenings while she did her homework, and who immersed herself in Victorian novels, romantic poetry and the great Hollywood films of the Forties. A conscientious eldest child growing up in Stockport during the war and ration years, passing the 11-plus, going to grammar school, getting good grades, and dreaming of Betty Grable, Rita Hayworth and Ava Gardner with their silk gowns and lipsticked, dangerous allure. Dreaming of leaving. Of being someone else, somewhere different.

She knew there was a place called university, though no one in her family had ever been there. She knew that this was her route away from her roots. A gulf was growing between her and her parents, who had themselves struggled so hard to leave their working class backgrounds for the lower middle classes. Her aspiration was also a kind of rejection. Success was a kind of betrayal.

Joan Bakewell is now in her mid-sixties, and emotionally in a 'bit of a beached' place since her 25-year marriage to her second husband Jack Emery ended a few months ago. 'It's hard at 66,' she says with a wry grimace and no self-pity.

She has an eloquent, graceful face, with her large eyes, her dark, gleaming hair, her fine, determined features. She has a firm chin that she keeps - literally and metaphorically - up. There is a luminous quality about her that is immensely attractive, and a kind of pluck. She sits on a sofa in her beautiful house in Primrose Hill - large rooms, tall windows through which sunlight slants, and outside a square of golden trees, scattering their leaves on the grass - immaculate in her black suit and black T-shirt.

She still would not call herself beautiful, however often the epithet has been given to her. Nor, she insists, has she ever thought herself so ('I simply do the best I can'). But for many years - over three decades - her public has known her as a woman who combines loveliness and good sense, who can be rather earnest, very sexy and studiously clever all at once.

She started her media career proper with the arts programme Late Night Line Up in the Sixties, and began a second career when for many years she presented The Heart of the Matter, the Sunday evening religious programme that debated ethical dilemmas. She resigned from that last year but still has several television projects on the boil - as well as being on Radio 3's Brains Trust, involved with the BBC's new digital cultural channel, on the board of the Tate (she was one of the jurors responsible for choosing the architect for the Tate Modern) and chair of the British Film Institute, whose London Film Festival opened last Wednesday. From going to the cinema twice a week as a movie-mad girl, now she's representing movies.

It's a long journey from post-war Joan Dawson Rowlands to postmodern Joan Bakewell, CBE, whose high cheekbones and long legs we know; whose seven-year affair with Harold Pinter, the subject of his play Betrayal, is now famous, whose crisp diction (learnt from elocution lessons that her mother insisted on) is still familiar. 'But I'm not a star,' she says. 'I never have been. I have a pretty average media life. I have never been on a ladder. It's not a career. I just work. I'm a worker.'

And she is, resilient and diligent, slogging on when so many around her disappear; a trouper.

Joan Bakewell speaks of her parents as being 'touchingly ordinary', yet the life of her mother is a painful narrative and clearly still casts shadows over the daughter who got away. Her mother, Rose, was the eldest of a large family, intelligent and ambitious (she wanted to be an engineer), who left school at 13 to look after her seven siblings. When she married Joan's father, whose own mother worked as a seamstress to within four hours of dying, the 'great honour of being lower middle class, no longer working class, was that the woman could stay at home - in a house where there was an indoor toilet and some kitchen facilities. My mother's job was to keep the home impeccable. She was very clever, but that was what she was taught to aspire to. It was a nightmare to live with. You could hardly dare put anything down. Everything had to be flawless; every last speck of dust had to be chased from the house.

'All her energies went into that. She was unhappy, and that snarled up our relationship. I remember her as silent - great stretches of silence. And she would hit me and my sister, smack us, a slap here, a flick of the wrist, a sharp tap. She was always terrified we would get pregnant before we got married. She made me secretive. I hid things from her. I took care not to get caught. I went to church. I was baptised and confirmed, I went to youth clubs, all sorts of jolly fresh air activities and maybe a bit of groping behind the youth club, holding hands, a peck on the cheek, and thinking, "more, more", but knowing because of what my mother said it was dangerous to want more.'

Cambridge (where she studied history) took her away from her parents, and introduced her to books, sex, pleasure, privileged young men and women with alien accents and love of learning. Her horizons opened. 'There was a whole world out there.' But she was still tied to her background ('I was rather Edwardian really') and she married her boyfriend, Michael Bakewell, because that was what you did, and started a family, because that was what you did, too. And gave up work as an advertising copywriter and occasional journalist (because ditto).

This was the Fifties: the great change of the Sixties was waiting in the wings, but in her twenties Joan Bakewell had both managed to escape and yet remained trapped by her gender and her sense of what was appropriate. 'I'm very conventional really, you know,' she says. 'It's a big thing for me, breaking the rules.'

Feminism and the Sixties changed her world and broke the rules for her, although she says that sometimes she regrets that it did not happen until she was in her thirties. 'I've been catching up ever since.'

Her life flowered with new pain and possibility. Her career took off, though it did not happen overnight. In 1964, when she was 30, she started work with Late Night Line Up on BBC2 (a Late Review of its day). Later she became the presenter of The Heart of the Matter and, consequently, a kind of national pin-up. She also started her seven-year affair with Pinter, a friend and colleague of her husband, (although in the middle of it she and Bakewell had another child, a son). The affair - which was an open secret in the world in which she moved - was only made public with Michael Billington's biography of Pinter. The playwright gave permission to Joan Bakewell to talk. (' "Really talk?" I said.').

She had been strictly brought up to believe that private lives should be kept private, and yet talk she did, speaking candidly of the passion and joy of those years, as well as the pain. She did not, she said then and repeats today, regret it. She chose to tell the story, she says to me now, because it was in an 'intelligent book'; it was long ago, everyone she cared about knew of the affair. It was time (though she drank a glass of wine beforehand to steady her nerve). The subsequent brouhaha took her by surprise.

She was 28 when her mother died, of leukaemia, a few years before her turbulent decade. The death brought Joan Bakewell a wrenching grief because everything between them remained so unresolved. 'It was not until I was in my mid-thirties, with the arrival of feminism, that I saw how clever she was, how thwarted, how terribly unhappy. We - my sister Susan and myself - found certificates in the drawers. All those classes she'd been to, learning about Beethoven, Picasso... always wanting to better herself. Seeing what I was doing with my life must have made her very wistful, I saw that at last. And then I could forgive her, when she was dead and it was too late.'

Her beloved father's death in 1992 gave her a softer grief, a grief she was almost glad of ('a deep and good grief'). He was in his eighties, and died in her arms. A few years later her younger sister died of breast cancer. 'When she told me about the cancer, I cried out, "You can't leave me." When she went it was part of my life that went - a visceral separation.'

She's not scared of death herself, but she's scared of losing other people. There has been other loss in her life. She and her first husband separated, after their 'mutual infidelities'. Now she and her second husband have also separated. 'Here I am, in my sixties, and I thought everything would go on the same, but it's become this strange period of change.' Everything is different. For almost the first time in her life, she is on her own, in a large house, her children gone, having to make sure she organises her time and fills her suddenly yawning weekends. Women friends, she says, have been 'completely wonderful' - a 'warm blanket' of love and support, 'a springboard so that I can go on'.

She sees her two children and their families often. She is a grandmother of six. When she talks of her grandchildren her face lights up. She is reading the celebrated children's author Philip Pullman at the moment so that she can keep in touch with their emergent worlds.

But sometimes she looks in the mirror and thinks 'oh my God, I'd forgotten about that. The neck goes. Around the eyes. No more skimpy frocks. No more of that utter freedom of being young. Fashion leaves you behind - I've always been interested in clothes but clothes are losing their interest in me. Except sexy shoes.

'But I don't feel post-sexual, although at this moment I am incapacitated a bit. I don't see myself as living in a neutered reality. I don't think that women ever need to feel like that - maybe they often feel like that because that's how other people see them.

'I went to the Maudsley Hospital the other day,' she goes on. 'I was interviewing a doctor who treats children, and on her shelves there were all these generic dolls, you know - the boy with genitals, the little girl doll, the woman, the man. And there was this doll with crinkly grey hair and little spectacles on the end of her nose and wearing slippers with bobbles on. "What's that?" I asked, and she said, "That's granny." "But I'm a granny," I said, "Look at me, this is what grannies look like. We wear high heels, nice clothes, have lives." I'm a granny and I work and I go to the gym and I've just bought myself a sporty little car.

'Feminism has hit the 60-year-olds. We've had feminist women writing and talking about being young, working, trying to bring up children, marrying, divorcing, going through the menopause. And now at last we've got to feminism that's talking about the reality of getting old. This is what it's like. Of course, friends do begin to die and we are approaching death ourselves, but we're not all Yeatsian - when you are old and grey and nodding by the fire and that kind of thing.

'No. I was fearful of death in my twenties and my thirties. Now I know it. I've seen it and recognised it and held it in my arms. It doesn't have to be terrifying, although it is always awesome.'

You have to keep on changing, she says; making new challenges. You have to have self-knowledge and when things are hard you must wait and be receptive. You have to keep on being interested in life. 'I've been unhappy, of course. There have been terribly unhappy times, but usually I take a delight in life. I am,' she smiles elegantly, 'an optimistic little bee.'

Feminism and the Sixties changed her world and broke the rules for her, although she says that sometimes she regrets that it did not happen until she was in her thirties. 'I've been catching up ever since.' Her life flowered with new pain and possibility. Her career took off, though it did not happen overnight. In 1964, when she was 30, she started work with Late Night Line Up on BBC2 (a Late Review of its day). Later she became the presenter of The Heart of the Matter and, consequently, a kind of national pin-up. She also started her seven-year affair with Pinter, a friend and colleague of her husband, (although in the middle of it she and Bakewell had another child, a son). The affair - which was an open secret in the world in which she moved - was only made public with Michael Billington's biography of Pinter. The playwright gave permission to Joan Bakewell to talk. (' "Really talk?" I said.'). She had been strictly brought up to believe that private lives should be kept private, and yet talk she did, speaking candidly of the passion and joy of those years, as well as the pain. She did not, she said then and repeats today, regret it. She chose to tell the story, she says to me now, because it was in an 'intelligent book'; it was long ago, everyone she cared about knew of the affair. It was time (though she drank a glass of wine beforehand to steady her nerve). The subsequent brouhaha took her by surprise. She was 28 when her mother died, of leukaemia, a few years before her turbulent decade. The death brought Joan Bakewell a wrenching grief because everything between them remained so unresolved. 'It was not until I was in my mid-thirties, with the arrival of feminism, that I saw how clever she was, how thwarted, how terribly unhappy. We - my sister Susan and myself - found certificates in the drawers. All those classes she'd been to, learning about Beethoven, Picasso... always wanting to better herself. Seeing what I was doing with my life must have made her very wistful, I saw that at last. And then I could forgive her, when she was dead and it was too late.' Her beloved father's death in 1992 gave her a softer grief, a grief she was almost glad of ('a deep and good grief'). He was in his eighties, and died in her arms. A few years later her younger sister died of breast cancer. 'When she told me about the cancer, I cried out, "You can't leave me." When she went it was part of my life that went - a visceral separation.' She's not scared of death herself, but she's scared of losing other people. There has been other loss in her life. She and her first husband separated, after their 'mutual infidelities'. Now she and her second husband have also separated. 'Here I am, in my sixties, and I thought everything would go on the same, but it's become this strange period of change.' Everything is different. For almost the first time in her life, she is on her own, in a large house, her children gone, having to make sure she organises her time and fills her suddenly yawning weekends. Women friends, she says, have been 'completely wonderful' - a 'warm blanket' of love and support, 'a springboard so that I can go on'. She sees her two children and their families often. She is a grandmother of six. When she talks of her grandchildren her face lights up. She is reading the celebrated children's author Philip Pullman at the moment so that she can keep in touch with their emergent worlds. But sometimes she looks in the mirror and thinks 'oh my God, I'd forgotten about that. The neck goes. Around the eyes. No more skimpy frocks. No more of that utter freedom of being young. Fashion leaves you behind - I've always been interested in clothes but clothes are losing their interest in me. Except sexy shoes. 'But I don't feel post-sexual, although at this moment I am incapacitated a bit. I don't see myself as living in a neutered reality. I don't think that women ever need to feel like that - maybe they often feel like that because that's how other people see them. 'I went to the Maudsley Hospital the other day,' she goes on. 'I was interviewing a doctor who treats children, and on her shelves there were all these generic dolls, you know - the boy with genitals, the little girl doll, the woman, the man. And there was this doll with crinkly grey hair and little spectacles on the end of her nose and wearing slippers with bobbles on. "What's that?" I asked, and she said, "That's granny." "But I'm a granny," I said, "Look at me, this is what grannies look like. We wear high heels, nice clothes, have lives." I'm a granny and I work and I go to the gym and I've just bought myself a sporty little car. 'Feminism has hit the 60-year-olds. We've had feminist women writing and talking about being young, working, trying to bring up children, marrying, divorcing, going through the menopause. And now at last we've got to feminism that's talking about the reality of getting old. This is what it's like. Of course, friends do begin to die and we are approaching death ourselves, but we're not all Yeatsian - when you are old and grey and nodding by the fire and that kind of thing. 'No. I was fearful of death in my twenties and my thirties. Now I know it. I've seen it and recognised it and held it in my arms. It doesn't have to be terrifying, although it is always awesome.' You have to keep on changing, she says; making new challenges. You have to have self-knowledge and when things are hard you must wait and be receptive. You have to keep on being interested in life. 'I've been unhappy, of course. There have been terribly unhappy times, but usually I take a delight in life. I am,' she smiles elegantly, 'an optimistic little bee.'

webTitle: Moral Muse: Should I just let him fade away?

fields.headline: Should I just let him fade away?
fields.trailText: When my husband and I first separated, he came to see our daughter regularly but his visits have now become less frequent because, he says, he cannot bear seeing me.
fields.body:
I am in the process of divorcing my husband of five years. We have a two-year-old daughter. When we first separated, he came to see her regularly but his visits have now become less frequent because, he says, he cannot bear seeing me.

So far, I have done nothing to encourage him because, although my rational self is keen for him to stay in contact with us so that he and our daughter can build a relationship, there's a part of me that would not be sorry to see him fade away.

He has an alcohol problem which has worsened over the years, and I worry what kind of a role model he will be and whether our daughter will be able to cope with his problems.

Should I encourage him to see her regularly or let him quietly drift away?
A.M. of Lincoln

Pay no heed to sexual political correctness. It is characteristic of a mother to show more forward planning for her daughter's welfare than the father does, especially where a couple has split up. It is also characteristic that he should blame you for his own pattern of defaulting and that you should meekly accept the accusation.

Yes, it is right and proper that your daughter should grow up knowing and associating with her own father. You don't need to be told this, though I daresay he does. Her needs and rights are paramount; his are of much less consequence.

It is possible, even probable, that you will marry again and give her a new father-figure to whom she will relate comfortably. But whatever happens, there will come a time, probably in her teenage years, when she will show curiosity about her origins and, if contact has been lost, will move heaven and earth to find out about her dad. Far better that they should keep in touch so that there are no shock revelations at a future date.

You can't force him to visit his child, probably you can't influence his response to duty at all, but you can pave the way, make it easier for him to fulfil his obligations. Use your feminine tact and find a solution. For instance, could your mother stand in when he visits so you don't have to meet? You would soon find out how genuine his intentions are.

His alcohol problem would not worry me overmuch in regard to his potential as a role model. With plenty of good examples and guidance, she will form her own judgments, sooner than you think.

Regrettably, when two people have created a child, they are bound together by indissoluble links, and you will never be able to obliterate him altogether. As you are currently in the throes of divorce, your level of mutual bitterness will be at its highest. In the course of time, the antipathy will moderate and problems which now seem insuperable will become manageable.

Reader's response

I have a two-year-old son by my ex-husband. We separated after a similar length of time to you and I, too, have concerns as to whether he is a suitable person to act as a role model for my little boy.

You will find that a lot of well-meaning people will try to lecture you on the importance of ensuring that your daughter keeps in touch with both parents. This is absolutely true where there is a genuine commitment from both parents to maintaining the contact.

But where one parent is unreliable, feckless or only insisting on access in order to enact some kind of revenge or control over their former partner, then what good is served by seeking to maintain contact out of some misplaced feeling of social duty?

If your ex-partner was truly committed to seeing your daughter, he would not be put off seeing her by having to see you every time he arrives for an access visit. You have to think of your daughter's happiness and, as the stable parent in her life, you have a duty to protect her from unnecessary pain.
L.R. of London

Next week's problem

My partner and I have a three-year-old daughter and although I am happy with one child, my partner is very keen for us to have another baby. I wouldn't mind but, as I work only part-time, the cost of child-care would exceed my earnings.

My partner is happy to compensate me and I would not find it hard to live without my career. The dilemma I have is becoming financially dependent on somebody else.

Should I give up my independence for the sake of my family?
E.H. OF Cambridgeshire

 Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.

fields.headline: Want to get rich? Then throw those schoolbooks away
fields.standfirst: Writer Robert Kiyosaki is wealthy after twice going bankrupt, he tells Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Writer Robert Kiyosaki is wealthy after twice going bankrupt, he tells Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
The worst financial advice you can give a child, says author Robert Kiyosaki, is to urge them to get an education and a good job. 'Financial struggle is often the result of people working all their lives for someone else,' he says in his book Rich Dad, Poor Dad . 'Many people will have nothing at the end of their working lives.'

This new, highly readable book, a bestseller in the United States, is a plea to the middle classes to move away from their long-held desire for job security (and relative poverty) and to become more entrepreneurial (and probably more wealthy).

Born 53 years ago in Hawaii, Kiyosaki was the son of the state superintendent of education. While his father urged him to go the traditional route of academic education and job security, he was more impressed with the views of his best friend's father, his 'rich dad', who questioned traditional academic education and preferred acquiring real estate. Kiyosaki, a millionaire several times over after being down-and-out twice, is proof of his own pudding. While other 53-year-olds are commuting to the City and worrying about pensions and mortgages, Kiyosaki has been retired from his business activities for six years. He spends his time driving his fast cars, devoting himself to financial education and lecturing because he enjoys it, as well as travelling.

He and his wife Kim, also financially astute, live in a large house in Arizona, following their own interests - she gives large charitable donations to animal protection charities; he gives to environmental organisations and runs his Foundation for Financial Literacy.

After beating the survival odds as a helicopter pilot in the Vietnam war, he went into the hat, wallet and bag trade. He twice went bust. On one of these occasions, he and Kim lived for three weeks in a car. 'For a man looking at my beautiful young wife, it hurt,' he says. 'It was male failure. But it inspired me to shape up.'

He learnt a lesson, he says, and it made him tougher. Part of the reason he never gives money to beggars is that they haven't yet learnt the lessons of their failure: 'Giving a poor person money keeps them poor. Intelligent people should learn from their experiences. With people on the street, the bad experience has beaten them.'

Part of the reason he went bankrupt, he says, was that he couldn't accept the child labour of bag, wallet and handbag manufacture. So he hadn't become the bad, greedy person his father had feared? No, he says. 'Money is a magnifier of what you are already.

If you are greedy, it will make you greedier. My family are all teachers, and genetically I'm a teacher. Since retiring, I've taught more and more. Ironically, I'm making more money. You make more money if you're generous.'

How do other people do this? First, do not lock yourself into a pile of financial commitments and a salary that only rises once a year. Buy assets that work for you even when you're asleep - in businesses that interest you or in shares. His book explains the psychological and practical steps. You don't need academic qualifications to do well: 'My bank manager never asked me for my report card,' he says with a laugh.

 Rich Dad, Poor Dad, £9.99, is published by Little Brown.

fields.headline: New Man is back - again
fields.standfirst: Just when it seemed that New Lad had elbowed out New Man, the tables have been turned
fields.trailText: Just when it seemed that New Lad had elbowed out New Man, the tables have been turned.
fields.body:
The New Man recometh. A suitably ugly pun for the re-emergence of a far from attractive phenomenon. Last month, at the fifth annual GQ awards in New York, it was revealed which of their peers American 'guys' most admire.

And on what was by all accounts an emotional evening at the Beacon Theatre in , statuettes were handed over to newscaster Ted Koppel, Matthew Broderick, Pierce Brosnan and Michael J. Fox, who became the first man in history to win two GQs on the bounce.

A strange quartet, the significance of which wasn't missed by Zeitgeist-watchers in the media. Moving confidently from the particular to the general, they announced that 'the American male looks up to those generally short in stature, hard-working, self-effacing and devoted to children and wives on whom they presumably don't cheat'. This was a sentence which not only contains a wonderful use of 'presumably' but also heralds the launch of New Man Mark II. Because, of course, when America 'goes there' the rest of us feel compelled to follow.

Of course, no geist-watcher worth his or her zeit would base such a seismic conclusion on the basis of a single, possibly rigged, vote. There was plenty of confirmatory evidence. This month alone, Details has informed its predominantly male readership how to make jam and Maxim ran a feature on plumbing. David Granger, editor-in-chief at Esquire , is in no doubt that change is afoot. 'They [men] want to know how to tuck their shirts in. There's an innate desire to know how to do things and a reluctance to ask. Men don't want to ask each other how to iron their pants. We all want to appear to be Masters of the Universe.'

Now you may think that a universe in which men aspire to tuck their shirt into a pair of ironed 'pants' is one of limited ambition but that is neither here nor there. What is significant is that it appears that straight men are taking an interest in fashion, which is a sure sign that some New Man thing is about to kick in again.

Let me take you back to a 1990 headline from the Guardian : 'Women: love, lust and phoney baloney - is the New Man an impossible dream, a dangerous and elaborate con or a phenomenon we should give the support denied us in the early days of feminism?' The conclusion to the two-part article was as follows: 'Disassociating misogyny from masculinity is the obstacle that stands in the way of our acceptance of New Men.'

Crikey. Was it that close? Was everything really that serious back in 1990? I have a vague memory that it may have been. A hazy recollection of depressing conversations in north London with A Poet who was unpublished then and is unpublishable now:

Will: So there I was sitting in this pub waiting for this girl...

Poet: Sorry?

Will: So there I was sitting in the Barrel of Laughs waiting for this girl.

Poet: How old was this girl? Fourteen?

Will: No, no, no. [Pause] I dunno - mid-twenties?

Poet: A woman, then. Not a girl. Surely even you must realise how offensive the term girl is to a fully mature woman... (and so on and so forth).

Yes, depressing times, but I'm sure I took them on the chin. Even when a girlfriend gave me a course of yoga lessons for Christmas, I managed to say thank you rather than ask for a receipt so I could claim a refund. Mind you, have you ever tried to get money back from the Inner London Education Authority?

Strange times. When unmasculine men played the New Man card as hard as they could, regularly leaking damaging misogynist stories about their love rivals in a desperate attempt to get a shag, it didn't work and it didn't last. Within a year, New Man was washed-up. Within three years, a speaker at the first-ever conference dedicated to marketing to men was saying: 'Women created New Man, but they also suffocated and killed him when they found him to be utterly unsexy.'

At the same conference, research was published showing that the only domestic area where men had improved was 'the purchase of groceries' where they scored an eyebrow-raising 30 per cent. But, and forgive me if I've got my trends in the wrong order, doesn't this coincide exactly with the fad for treating supermarkets like singles bars? The so-called New Man may have returned with the apples and pears but he had travelled hopefully to Tesco in search of something entirely different.

Indeed, the primary reason underlying his emergence may have been economic rather than sociological. Back in 1990, there was chronic unemployment, and Norman Lamont hadn't even become Chancellor. More and more men were stuck at home looking for something to do (remember Sky hadn't secured the rights to broadcast the Premiership) and quite prepared to have a crack at changing a nappy while his wife minded the other three kids with one hand and worked away at her part-time job with the other.

When the economy picked up and men, becoming more confident, realised that women didn't fancy new men... along came the New Lads. Which was refreshing for about two- and-half minutes. But the New Lads had a similar lifespan to the New Man. And then came the 'postmodernly ironic lads', a social grouping too far. Which perhaps explains why we've come full circle to New Man Mk II.

All that laddism may have blunted my mind but I now find it unfathomably difficult to locate a single example of a New Man Mk I. Who the hell was he? Who appeared on the Newsnight filler-slot in the early Nineties to discuss, sensitively, the changing role of men in society? Was there an anti-Clarkson before Clarkson?

No one knows. All I can dredge up is a vague memory of Paul Gascoigne being heralded as the archetypal New Man for bursting into tears, although, with hindsight, placing Gascoigne in the vanguard of a movement dedicated to 'disassociating misogyny from masculinity' might have been ill-judged.

Perhaps, the movement will fare better second time round with another footballer at the helm - David Beckham. He's a nice lad, loves clothes and is devoted to both Brooklyn and Victoria, on whom he presumably doesn't cheat. Even better, he is best friends with Gary and Phil Neville and you can't get more self-effacing than that. He seems a natural figurehead.

Only last week, Parky, once again blaming someone else, remarked to him: 'David, the tabloids have had a field day with your more feminine side.'

A feminine footballer - it's what New Men have been waiting for.

Perhaps, the movement will fare better second time round with another footballer at the helm - David Beckham. He's a nice lad, loves clothes and is devoted to both Brooklyn and Victoria, on whom he presumably doesn't cheat. Even better, he is best friends with Gary and Phil Neville and you can't get more self-effacing than that. He seems a natural figurehead. Only last week, Parky, once again blaming someone else, remarked to him: 'David, the tabloids have had a field day with your more feminine side.' A feminine footballer - it's what New Men have been waiting for.

fields.headline: How woeful Widows cut my windfall
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
My Scottish Widows policy was assigned to me in 1993 when I divorced, but the company continued to put my ex-husband's name on communications sent to my address. A year ago, the company said I was the qualifying member for the merger payout, and I opted for loan notes as I recently sold a holiday cottage and had used my capital gains tax allowance for this year.

Again, the form was addressed to my ex-husband, but Scottish Widows told me that changing his name for mine was satisfactory.

My loan notes failed to arrive because, it was said, my form was one of 4 per cent randomly selected for checking. I was later told that compensation was suppressed because there was a query over who was the qualifying member, and that I would now be paid in cash.

Because of the delay, I will have to pay £3,600 in capital gains tax, although Scottish Widows knew from the outset that I was a qualifying member and required a loan note.
DD, Ilkley

The company agrees that it gave you inconsistent and conflicting information, and wrongly addressed the forms to your former husband. There was no random sampling.

A number of policyholders have been stuck with cash after requesting loan notes, but it looks as though you might be able to receive loan notes after all.

Scottish Widows revealed that it has had discussions with the Inland Revenue, which will now allow more loan notes to be issued in certain circumstances, in particular where the company has made a mistake.

The insurer will be in touch with you when it has more information.

Hope of cover is a write-off

On 29 February our neighbour's wall fell on our car when it was parked in the street. Through our insurance company, Royal & SunAlliance, the car was repaired but I still had to pay the first £100 of the bill.

Last June, R&SA said there was no reasonable prospect of pursuing the claim successfully and, after giving me 14 days to comment, it planned to close the file. I responded to its letter, but have heard nothing since the middle of September.

Is it not a standard clause in house contents policies that the policyholder is indemnified against financial loss incurred by a third party?
SP, Bath

The weakness in the third party liability clause is that, for a claim to be successful, you have to prove the other person was at fault.

If your neighbour says she had no idea the that wall was weak, you have to prove that she did know and did nothing about it.

But now, even though R&SA has given up hope of making the other side pay up, it has agreed to give you £100 as an ex gratia payment.

Lawyer's error cost me a bonus

I redeemed my mortgage with the Skipton Building Society when I bought a new property this June. Due to an oversight by my solicitor, the Skipton did not receive payment until 3 July. It claimed this took my account into another month, for which I was liable to pay an extra month's interest of £200.

Some weeks later, I discovered that the society was making loyalty payments, but was told that I had to have a mortgage with them on 19 July to qualify, and my mortgage was redeemed on 3 July.

I did not qualify, even though I had to pay interest to the end of July.
LH, Huddersfield

With all payouts and bonuses, there is a cut-off date, which is bad luck for those who just miss out.

You had already paid a £45 discharge fee to the Skipton, but its rules say that you pay interest to the end of the month in which a mortgage is redeemed. If your solicitor was at fault for the late payment, you should trying talking to him about compensation for being forced to pay an extra month's interest.

Skipton staff were deliberately kept in the dark about the loyalty bonus, as happens with all bonuses, until they arrived for work on 19 July, so no one could have forewarned you.

Insurer claws elderly cats

My two cats have been insured against vets' bills with DBI Insurance continuously since they were a few months old. They are now aged 11, and the renewal notice shows the premiums are rising by 52 per cent, there is a mandatory excess of £40 and I then have to pay 35 per cent of any remaining bill.

Previously, the company charged the same premium regardless of the animal's age and whether or not the owner lived in a low-cost area, as I do.

I was prepared to pay over the odds for insuring my cats when they were young on the tacit understanding that cover would continue at a reasonable cost as my pets grew older. DBI's abrupt change of policy means that I am penalised.
JT, Beaumaris

DBI (Dog Breeders Insurance) says premiums were bumped up by its new owner, Cornhill, because it had been trading unprofitably. This is no consolation to policyholders like you who were not expecting such a leap in cost. DBI says insuring a cat of 11 is £7.55 a month. Primary Direct insures younger cats for £5 a month, but you are trapped because no one will start insuring cats as old as yours.

Cancelled cheque: Did it check out?

I paid for shares in a new company with a £2,000 building society cheque. The offer was cancelled, and the cheque returned. I thought, wrongly, that at least my money was safely back in my account. Just in time I stopped myself from tearing it up and, when I asked at the branch what would have happened, I was told: 'You would have lost £2,000.'
LS, Leicester

That is wrong. If you had destroyed the returned cheque, or it had been stolen, the money would have been returned to your account once the building society had proved your story. You cannot cancel third-party cheques but the building society can, if you report one lost or stolen. You lose interest between taking the cheque and paying it back in, so you should get it back into your account fast.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Mortgage rules | Stakeholder line | High-flyer credit
fields.body:
Mortgage rules

Legal controls on the selling of mortgages came a step closer last week with publication by the Financial Services Authority of a consultation paper on how it will implement the Government's decision to regulate homeloans. Proposals include measures to improve advertising and marketing of loans and information on how loans compare. They aim to make it easier for homeowners to make sense of the thousands of loans on offer. Consumer groups remain angry, however, that the Government is not proposing to regulate advice from lenders.

Stakeholder line

A government helpline has been launched to give information and guidance on stakeholder pensions. Staff will not be able to give advice on whether someone should have a stakeholder pension or where to buy one, but will give information on how schemes will operate, employers' obligations and how new pensions fit in with existing pension arrangements. Tel: 0845 601 2923

High-flyer credit

New credit cards offering a 'fast-track' way for members of British Airways' frequent flyers' programme - the BA UK Executive Club - to earn free British Airways flights. The three cards, to be launched on 5 January, will offer one BA airmile for every £1 spent on the card. The cards will have annual fees ranging from £20 to £160. Interest on debt transfers will be at 4.9 per cent, and from 17.9 to 19.9 per cent for new purchases. Tel: 0808 100 0075

What's the catch?

Marketbet.com offers you the chance to cut your teeth on the stock market by gambling as little as £1. It may be a small wager, but the chances of winning the main prize are slim.

The two games are Share Selector and Finger the Footsie. In Share Selector players try to pick the eight best-performing FTSE shares over a week from 60 listed by Marketbet. Each 'line' costs £1. Winnings are a guaranteed minimum jackpot of £250,000. Chances of winning are millions to one even if you bet the maximum of 165 lines a week.

A spokesman for the company says: 'We managed to get insurance for the jackpot as insurers are confident you won't win.' Since Marketbet started on 11 September, no one has won.

With Finger the Footsie the odds are better but the winnings smaller. Players predict the closing price of the FTSE 100 index on a particular day. The closest to the figure at close of play wins the day's takings. The prize pool is usually 'a couple of hundred pounds'.

Marketbet.com targets would-be investors who are reluctant to try investment due to lack of money or high share-dealing costs. Managing director Mike Hollings says: 'This way you get all the thrills and spills of the stock market without the risks.'

He contrasts it spread-betting, where you can make £20,000, but equally lose the same amount by trying to beat the bookmaker's predictions.

He says marketbet differs from the lottery as winning is not just a matter of luck - you can narrow the odds by spotting a trend.

fields.headline: Class action - on a plate
fields.standfirst: You could hit a rich seam by buying ceramic memorabilia of the Eighties miners' strike, writes  John Windsor
fields.trailText: You could hit a rich seam by buying ceramic memorabilia of the Eighties miners' strike, writes John Windsor.
fields.body:
Ceramic plates commemorating pit closures and the coal miners' strike of 1984-85 have become popular in the Midlands and the North. But in London and the south they are virtually unknown.

Sons and grandsons of miners buy them in weekend markets as mementos. In the South, they now seem likely to become collectable political chic, as the miners' strike takes its place in history as the biggest confrontation between government and labour since the General Strike.

As many as 650 editions of the 10.5 inch dinner plates have been issued - a potential collector's dream. They were first published by branches of the National Union of Mineworkers to raise welfare funds. More recently, ex-miners who recall the events of 1984-85 with bitterness and passion have been originating their own editions.

Andrew Bradley, jailed for nine months during the strike for cutting an electricity cable and bringing Markham colliery, Nottinghamshire, to a standstill, has designed 20 plates, including one marking the tenth anniversary of the strike.

A leaked National Coal Board plan to close between 75 and 95 pits provoked the strike, and his plate charts the decimation of the coal industry that followed. It says: '1984 - 170 pits, 191,000 miners: 1994 - 17 pits, 10,771 miners.'

Among the most strident images to be found on mining plates are a police horse rearing over picket lines with a truncheon-wielding policeman in the saddle, a gaunt-looking mining family, and a lump of coal shedding blood. They commemorate not only a government-union collision that turned coalfields into battlefields, but a conflict that set striker against non-striker in what had been closely knit communities and widened the North-South divide.

On the back of the plates is some memorably vitriolic prose, such as this from the strike plate of the NUM branch at Arkwright colliery, Derbyshire, which celebrates the names of 97 men who obeyed the union's nationwide strike call: 'After God had finished the rattlesnake, the toad and the vampire, he had some awful substance left, out of which he made a scab. A scab is a two-legged animal with a corkscrew soul, a waterlogged brain and a combination backbone of jelly and glue. When a scab comes down the street men turn their backs, the angels weep in Heaven, and the devil shuts the gates of hell to keep him out.'

Some editions are becoming scarce, notably 'end-of-an-era' plates. Some were presented to redundant miners by National Coal Board officials as they stepped out of the lift cage after their last shift. Outraged, many smashed them on the spot.

One such rarity is the first mining plate made by Ed-wards & Lockett, the Stoke-on-Trent firm that has since issued about 600 editions of plates - nearly all that exist. Published in 1982 for the NUM, the plate marks the closure that year of the Bilsthorpe, Nottingham-shire, colliery. Les Lockett, founder of Edwards & Lockett, says he has been offered £300 for his one remaining sample. Adrian Loftus of Newark, the biggest dealer in mining plates, says he could sell Bilsthorpe 1982 plates for £100 each - if only he could get hold of them.

Edwards & Lockett's stocks are dwindling, but copies remain of about 100 of their editions. Loftus, who deals in both the secondary and ex-factory markets, sells NUM plates that are still in stock for £14-£17 - a low-price policy that has won him an exclusive concession from the NUM to sell plates commissioned by the union, he says.

Some other dealers at Midlands weekend markets charge £20 for run-of-the-mill mining plates. And at the National Coal Mining Museum at Caphouse Colliery, West Yorkshire, the going rate is £22.50 for their Grimethorpe, Frickley South and Elmsall pit closure plates published by the National Coal Board. Loftus sells these for £14.

No collector's guide to mining platesexists, which makes it difficult to judge rarity and value without expert advice. At a Derbyshire market recently, a saucer-sized plate made by AJL Giftware of Stoke-on-Trent showing national NUM president Arthur Scargill during the strike as 'Old King Coal' was bought for £20. Loftus offered me as many of them as I wanted for £1 each. Some plates are numbered but do not reveal the size of the edition. Lockett, however, says his firm's editions have seldom topped 500.

Lockett, who is 79, first worked down the pit as a coal wagon hauler at the age of 14 His strike plates, sold wholesale to union branches for about £2 each, yielded two or three times that in aid of miners' welfare.

As for the plates' strong language, Lockett raises his hands in a gesture of innocence: 'Customers' instructions,' he says. 'We've always been completely impartial.'

Loftus worked for more than two years down the pit, from the age of 17. The memory of it arouses little passion in him but the fate of his father does. He died from emphysema aged 62 after working 36 years at Bilsthorpe, most of the time at the coal face.

'I'm bitter,' says Loftus, a Labour councillor in Newark, 'and these plates are one way of keeping the memory of the miners alive.' Instead of smashing his Bilsthorpe 'end of an era' plate - now the most valuable - Adrian's father gave it to him. It was the first of his collection of 250 mining plates.

As collecting mining plates becomes more sophisticated, plates by known designers, such as Pete Fidler, last NUM president at Sherwood colliery, Nottinghamshire, will acquire a following. He has designed 18 plates, produced by Edwards & Lockett and sold by Loftus, including the tenth anniversary strike plate, in a big edition of 5,000, in collaboration with Andrew Bradley (price £15).

Besides quoting a decade of pit closures, the pit juxtaposes a letter of 1984 from the NCB chairman, Ian MacGregor, denying his intention to 'butcher the industry' with one dated a month later by Arthur Scargill predicting the closure of 'around 86 pits with the loss of over 70,000 jobs'. The plate asks: 'Who told the truth?'

No fewer than seven Sherwood colliery plates have been published - three by the NUM, two by the UDM, one by the National Coal Board, and one by the National Association of Colliery Overmen, Deputies and Shotfirers.

Would-be investors might consider collecting the Durham NUM strike plate showing police horses in action, worth £30, the scarce original Teversal (Nottinghamshire) closure plate of 1980, which changes hands for £150, or the Ollerton (Nottinghamshire) strike plate, an edition of only 120, of which one was given to each of the 117 strikers and only three sold. It sells for £50-£100.

For my money, £15 spent on the Arkwright anti-scab diatribe is as good a buy as any.

More information

Edwardian Fine China (Edwards & Lockett) (01782-319792).
AJ Loftus Mining Memorabilia (01636-6407 59).

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Jupiter European Opportunities Trust
fields.trailText: Jupiter European Opportunities Trust
fields.body:
Contact: 0500 0500 98 or www.jupiteronline.co.uk

Aim: To produce long-term growth through investment in western European companies.

Bells & whistles: A conventional (ordinary shares only) trust run by Alex Darwall who, while running Jupiter's split capital European investment trust, has achieved growth of 210 per cent over the last two years and 109 per cent in the last year.

How it works: Darwall will pick companies both inside and outside the eurozone. The trust has access to gearing worth up to 45 per cent of its asset value, meaning it can borrow this money to invest in shares that the trust could not otherwise afford to buy. This will enhance returns to investors provided the shares rise, but will increase investors' losses if share prices fall. The trust has a fixed lifespan which ends on 29 February, 2008. webTitle: Heather Connon: Less income the price for less risk

fields.headline: Less income the price for less risk
fields.trailText: Anyone who invests in corporate bonds should be aware of the risk that they will not get all their money back. The income is not guaranteed, either.
fields.body:
Anyone who invests in corporate bonds should be aware of the risk that they will not get all their money back. What they may have been less aware of, however, is that the income is not guaranteed, either. Last month's decision by CGU to slash the income on its hugely popular Monthly Income Plus fund by almost a fifth was a sharp reminder of that, and a severe blow to its 170,000 investors. But CGU's move should not be seen as a reason to bale out of corporate bonds.

The move was certainly a surprise. The value of corporate bonds - effectively loan notes issued by companies - has been falling over the past couple of years as investors worry about the impact of rising interest rates and, more recently, high borrowings by telecoms companies, which have been very active in the corporate bond market.

But the price of a bond does not affect the income from it: the interest payable is set when it is issued. The income will only fall if the company issuing the bond goes bust or stops paying its interest bill. So far, there have been no defaults, as these are called, in Britain.

Performance tables show that the capital value of the average fund has fallen by 4 per cent over the past two years. But if you include the value of the income, the average return has been a passable 6 per cent.

CGU's move was brought about by two circumstances peculiar to that fund. First, it invested far more in preference shares than most other corporate bond funds. These are similar to ordinary shares except that they pay a fixed dividend and, recently, their performance has been even worse than corporate bonds. The fund has been cutting its exposure to preference shares and, rivals say, reinvesting the proceeds in higher quality corporate bonds. These may be less volatile than prefs but the downside is that they produce a lower income. As the fund's income fell, so it had to cut the amount it was paying to investors.

Other funds insist that their payouts are secure. Aberdeen, which runs a high-yield bond fund offering a yield of 8.4 per cent - similar to CGU's before the pay-out was cut - says it has increased its income for the past six years and is optimistic it can do so again.

Investors, however, should look closely at what they are buying. The funds with the highest income are likely to be investing in bonds where the risk of default is higher. While it is true that defaults are extremely rare, they are rising in the US and there is growing concern about the impact of telecom company borrowings on the bond market. Anyone buying a higher-yielding fund should, therefore, be prepared for some turbulence.

The risks decrease as the income declines. M&G's Corporate Bond fund, for example, yields 6.1 per cent and has been increasing its investment in government gilts, which are safer than corporate bonds.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Equitable a winner? Life's moved on

fields.headline: Equitable a winner? Life's moved on
fields.trailText: Equitable Life seems determined to dig itself into an ever deeper public relations hole. The insurer is up for sale following a court order that it must honour guarantees on pensions it had sought to renege on.
fields.body:
Equitable Life seems determined to dig itself into an ever deeper public relations hole. The insurer is up for sale following a court order that it must honour guarantees on pensions it had sought to renege on.

The company's attitude throughout the fight has seemed out of character with the blameless record it had enjoyed until then. Not all of this has been undone by the guaranteed annuity fiasco, and if the right buyer is found much of the damage should be made good.

But Equitable is continuing to advertise its pensions with no reference to what is going on behind the scenes. Indeed, it is quoting awards it has received from us and the specialist magazine Money Management to put the rosiest possible view on its business.

Yes, Equitable did win these awards. In The Observer's case, readers voted for it because of its standards of service and their general satisfaction with a pension provider that had a well-deserved reputation for past value and help to customers. We pointed out then that despite readers' views there was a cloud hanging over Equitable. Yet its press advertising uses the award prominently, with no mention of the uncertainty.

In Money Management's case the award was based on straight facts about Equitable funds' past performance. But the magazine's editor feels it 'inappropriate' for Equitable to tout the awards like this.

As Personal Finance Editor of The Observer I also feel that Equitable is out of order in the way it is using the accolade given to it by readers and loyal customers. They deserve a higher standard of behaviour and, as we launch this year's consumer finance awards, we would urge readers to keep this in mind before proposing this company again.

Insurer Axa has been ordered to fund the costs of a legal challenge to the proposed deal it has offered policyholders for dividing its 'orphan' or excess assets. By the end of last week the insurer was warning that if the deal is thrown out policyholders will get nothing. This a bullying response to a decision that did not go the company's way.

In the longer term, this row also threatens to test the judgment of the Financial Services Authority, which sanctioned Axa's highly controversial proposal.

webTitle: Property: It's chic - but how is its 'chi'

fields.headline: It's chic - but how is its 'chi'
fields.standfirst: Is the feng shui right? What do the tarot cards say? There's more to buying a house than meets the eye, writes  Natalie Sutton
fields.trailText: Is the feng shui right? What do the tarot cards say? There's more to buying a house than meets the eye, writes Natalie Sutton.
fields.body:
Estate agents say the property market is about 'location, location, location'. Business people may be concerned with the commuting distance between work and home. Young families consider schools.

But for some people, ethereal influences and divination - the art of discovering future or unknown events - are seen as major forces when making decisions to buy or sell a home, even though such practices are less than rational.

Spiritual consultants are available in person, by telephone and now online to give readings and charts which are then interpreted as advice or guidance.

Feng shui, the Chinese belief in the importance of where things are placed, has become very popular in Britain over the past few years. It involves choosing and altering your environment to maximise your 'chi', or wellbeing.

According to leading consultant and the author of Quick Feng Shui Cures , Sarah Shurety, there are many ways of establishing whether a property and its immediate vicinity are conducive to an individual's harmony and this has to do with the vibration of an area supporting their particular 'chi'.

You should start by exploring the feel of a neighbourhood, looking out for negative signs such as dead animals on the road or people being less than friendly when asked for directions. On entering a house, the estate agent's key should turn smoothly in the lock and the lavatory should never be positioned opposite the front door.

It is apparently not only the way in which the house is designed and decorated that can affect your future happiness but fundamental issues such as the property's history, its position in relation to the sun and the wind, the amount of greenery surrounding it, its proximity to water as well as the time and geographical direction of your actual move. The list of dos and don'ts is long and a good place to start is at www.fengshuisite.com followed by a consultation relating specifically to you and your property.

Panchang is the Indian alternative with origins from 4,000 BC. This system uses the exact position of the Moon, the planets and zodiac signs at the time and place of birth to formulate a chart.

Panchang is a way for the individual to use timing to their advantage by, for example, calculating the best time to buy and sell property. Sam Chaffey consulted Michael Geary, a Panchang astro-loger, about her move from Devon.

Sam explained: "The property in Devon had slipped into negative equity and was proving impossible to sell. I was distraught at the prospect of not being able to move. However, Michael suggested an auspicious time to put the house on the market, and within the week we had found a buyer at the original asking price.' The sale went without a hitch.

According to Geary, timing is the key to success. 'For example,' he said, 'I advised one person on her house move recently. Her consultation suggested that she postpone putting the house on the market for a few weeks. She did so and the sale finalised at 40 per cent above the original asking price.'

But so too have a lot of house sales in the past year or so. This particular divination is available at www.panchang.com, where it claims to be able to 'ease the stress' of a house move.

The origins of tarot are uncertain, although it seems to have started as a card game handed down by gypsies travelling through Europe in the thirteenth century. Tarot readings are a selection of picture cards picked from a pack of 72 which allude to the fortune of the person asking a specific question.

Catriona was considering a move out of London to a cottage in Tyttenhanger, near St Albans. The reasons for moving to this area included an easy commute, good schools and the benefits of country living. The property seemed perfect. 'It had loads of character, was beautifully decorated and backed on to open fields,' she said. But at £275,000 it was more than their budget allowed so they put in an offer of £260,000 which was turned down.

Catriona first consulted her tarot reader on whether the move to St Albans was auspicious. The reader used a three-card spread as follows: the Three of Cups showed a happy group, seen as Catriona and her family. The second revealed the Hierophant, a card with strong religious overtones and therefore relevant to the city of St Albans. The third card represents the answer to the question asked, and in this case was the Hermit interpreted as Catriona's isolation if she left London.

The process was repeated asking whether Catriona should move to Tyttenhanger. The Hermit came up again as the first card which reinforced the tarot reader's concerns. The Ace of Pentacles related to the area and the outcome was the Five of Cups, a card of regret which pictured three cups having fallen down. In view of the previous reading, the tarot reader felt that this was very worrying and advised caution.

Meanwhile, the property was under offer twice from other buyers, but these potential deals fell through before Catriona spotted it advertised at a lower price. The cards were consulted again, this time with the actual cottage in mind to decide on whether Catriona should put in another offer.

The third tarot card in the reading showed the King of Cups whose throne is floating on water which greatly troubled the reader; a definite sign of unstable foundations. Catriona pressed the estate agent for further details as to why the house sale appeared to be so problematic. It was revealed that a property developer had bought the land behind the cottage and, rather than surrounding themselves with open fields, Catriona and her family could have found themselves on a housing estate. They decided to stay in London. 'I will always consult the tarot,' says Catriona. 'But it's only relevant if you are going to act on it.'

The tarot reader explained that often the symbolism depicted on the card only served to strengthen convictions which you had already. 'It's all about interpretation and often it can make you feel as though fortune is smiling on you,' she says.

There are other divinations you can consult when considering a move. Like Panchang, astrology, or the zodiac as we see it in horoscopes, usually relates to the time and place of your birth.

An astrological chart is drawn up focusing on birth as the most important symbolic time of life. From this, natal astrology dictates whether it is the right time to buy, sell or move, according to your individual chart. Horary astrology depends on the time at which a particular decision is made as to whether or not it is fortuitous. For example, an offer has been made on my flat, should I accept it?

Electional astrology makes it possible to elect a specific time to do something. For instance, completing on a certain date at a certain time although you would have to find an understanding solicitor to comply with this. Obviously, a combination of all three types of astrology is used to give a more detailed response to various questions and dilemmas.

Patricia, an astrologer advised her client who was considering a move from a flat to a larger property in a more affordable area to wait as something much closer to home seemed to be symbolised in her chart. Soon after wards, the flat below came up for sale offering the possibility of a cheap conversion and a less costly move while staying in the same area.

Numerology gives individuals a life path number which is reached by a calculation involving date of birth. House numbers come into play by suggesting a mood for the house which is or is not compatible with the life path number of its occupant.

Vaastu shastra is similar to feng shui and concentrates on the flow of energy through your body and your surroundings.

So next time you are gazing through an estate agent's window and you think you might fancy a change, think about where the house is positioned with regard to the elements and consider the time at which your birth dictates you should move.

Consult the tarot cards and beware the unlucky Hanged Man, and finally, if your life path number is four, don't even think of moving into number 57 because, among other things, you'd have to paint it violet to restore the karma and secure happy, fruitful relationships.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: No debts - but no pension

fields.headline: No debts - but no pension
fields.standfirst: Chris has £22,000 in Premium Bonds and £5,000 in the bank. Now he's wondering how best to safeguard his future, writes  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Chris has £22,000 in Premium Bonds and £5,000 in the bank. Now he's wondering how best to safeguard his future, writes Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Chris Snarski

Age 24

Lives in East Dulwich, south London

Occupation Technical support manager

Earns £28,000 including bonuses

Mortgage None

Debts None

Investments Premium Bonds

Pension None

Aims To sort out a pension, invest savings on the stock market and take out income protection insurance

Chris works for a small company which provides technical support services to the oil industry. He gets on well with his boss and each year sits down with him to decide a bonus which reflects his contribution to the company's profits. But he does not have a pension and he feels he should be doing something about it. He is not sure whether a personal pension or a company-sponsored scheme is more suitable.

Chris has always felt the need to save. 'I did not go to university as most of my friends did and have always worried about being out of employment. So I wanted to build up my savings to give myself some security.' So far his main choice of savings vehicle has been Premium Bonds. Over the past five years he has built up the maximum holding of £20,000 in bonds and has purchased a further £2,000 in his mother's name. He generally wins something every other month. His biggest win was £1,000, though for the last two months he has not been so lucky. He likes Premium Bonds because of the gambling aspect, the chance to win £1m without losing his stake. The National Lottery does not appeal so much although he occasionally buys scratch cards.

He is living in rented accommodation which he shares with friends. His rent is £300 per month. He has no wish to buy a home at present. 'With renting, you have no hassle and no responsibilities. When you buy, it means you have to settle down,' he says. However, he admits he has talked with a friend about buying a property to let as an investment somewhere outside London. But so far they have got no further than talking.

He is considering what to do with around £5,000 he has in his current account. He normally likes to keep the balance at about £2,000. He is debating whether to take out an ISA. But he was recently deterred when he read an article about several people who had bought ISAs earlier this year and had not made any money. Yet he would like to put something into the stock market and has considered buying shares direct.

Another concern is income protection insurance. He had a cycling accident a couple of years ago which 'put his hip out', and he has been suffering back problems ever since. He is worried that this might eventually affect his ability to work and would like to know if he can take out insurance to protect himself against this possibility.

He has no debts, not even a credit card, as he says he was brought up to save first before spending. His car is provided by his company. He has been in his job for two and a half years and expects to stay there for another year or two at least.

However, there is a possibility that he may travel abroad.

Adviser 1: Sharon Linnard

Chris is right to start thinking about pensions now. From next year his employer will have to offer a stakeholder pension under which charges will be very low and the contract very flexible.

Starting regular contributions when he is 25 could mean that Chris needs to pay perhaps no more than 10 or 11 per cent of his earnings to build up a reasonable pension. He could use some of the money in his current account to make a one-off payment to a pension. Some insurance companies already offer terms in line with the stakeholder regime and because he can pay net of basic rate tax, a payment of say £2,000 would be topped up to £2,546 with tax relief.

However, Chris may pre fer to put some money into an Isa. These are to be held for upwards of five years, and the fact that those taken out earlier this year have fallen in value should not be a deterrent.

His relatively large holding in Premium Bonds is understandable but, unless winnings are re-invested, the capital is being eroded by inflation.

Chris should ask an independent financial adviser about income protection cover. As he has had back problems, insurers might want a higher premium or an exclusion.

There is a case for Chris buying his own property. Rental accommodation can provide a good income.

Sharon Linnard works for KPMG.

Adviser 2: Gordon Wilson

The benefit of joining a company pension scheme is often undervalued. Although Chris's company does not have a pension scheme, a stakeholder scheme will have to be put in place next year.

As Chris gets on well with his boss, he could arrange in advance to give up part of his bonus which could be redirected into his pension, so reducing his personal tax bill. In addition, he could contemplate contracting out of the State Earnings Related Pension Scheme (Serps). fields.headline: Islanders' victory
fields.standfirst: But no thanks to the Foreign Office
fields.trailText: As the native inhabitants of the Chagos Islands win the right to return to their homeland and the British Government announces that it will not challenge the decision, we might be tempted to congratulate ourselves for being a kinder, more humane generation than the cold warriors of 1965 who sold the birthright of some 2,000 men, women and children under their colonial care for a discount on a nuclear submarine.
fields.body:
As the native inhabitants of the Chagos Islands win the right to return to their homeland and the British Government announces that it will not challenge the decision, we might be tempted to congratulate ourselves for being a kinder, more humane generation than the cold warriors of 1965 who sold the birthright of some 2,000 men, women and children under their colonial care for a discount on a nuclear submarine.

But we should learn the lessons of our so recent past. Britain lied to the world and its own citizens by claiming there was no indigenous population on the islands, then hid from Parliament, in the name of security, that it was transporting whole fishing communities to inner-city slums in an alien land. That successive British governments, learning the truth, failed to redress that gross injustice shames all involved. But the real villain is a secretive and patrician Foreign Office culture, and that remains with us to this day.

webTitle: Leader: Public spending is top priority

fields.headline: Public spending is top priority
fields.standfirst: Labour must argue the merits of tax
fields.trailText: Labour must argue the merits of tax
fields.body:
The coincidence of the worst autumn storms for 50 years, the discovery that up to 500 miles of the country's railway lines are unsafe and a `people's' revolt over petrol prices - coming as they do after the Phillips report on BSE - has created a sense of living in an irredeemably second-rate country.

The events seem unrelated, but are in truth linked by a single thread - Britain's weakness in asserting a democratically decided public interest. Our governmental institutions were not created to represent or inform the public or ensure that infrastructure from railway lines to flood defences receives the investment and support it should. Rather, they are the botched result of centuries of adaptation to a feudal model created by the conquering Normans. We need better today. Overlaid on this systemic weakness is 20 years of Tory dogma that there is nothing, even running a loss-making monopoly rail service, that the private sector cannot do better than government. Taxation has not been protected and legitimised as the necessary downpayment for creating the public goods that we need - education, transport and health. It has been denigrated as a `burden' to be minimised.

Meanwhile, the Treasury, product of an antique state and anti-state tradition, has scandalised generations with its scepticism towards public investment. It was against building Spitfires in the 1930s (low taxes and free markets were a better weapon with which to fight Hitler). It is automatically against any effort at public improvement, endowing the country with cheapskate transport, second-rate schools and, as we learned last week, third-rate flood defences. Its idiosyncratic system of public finance, which regards the build-up of public assets as less efficient than any private-sector counterpart, offends all international conventions.

Put all this together and we have what we have. Protesters who believe in the legitimacy of their anti-tax rhetoric; 10,000 evacuated from homes that in any other developed country would have been protected from floods; and a ramshackle rail system run by fly-blown, investment-averse private operators. The same deformations apply across the board; in our health service, our road network and throughout the public sector.

Labour, painfully late, has begun a programme of public investment. It is willing to take on the petrol protesters, arguing firmly on the merits of taxation and insisting that the rules of democracy must be followed. It is establishing an honourable position in preparing to use spare cash to improve the situation of pensioners rather than to buy off interest groups. We would like it to go further, and present its constitutional reforms as part of a process of modernising and legitimising government - in particular redrafting its Freedom of Information Act and accepting the case for a fully elected House of Lords. But we believe it has learned the lesson of recent events and deserves our support.

fields.headline: Dublin to speak in Northern tongue
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Ulster Scots - a language similar to Lallans, the native tongue of Scotland's most famous poet, Robert Burns - is set to be recognised as the republic's third official language.
fields.body:
Fancy a wild weekend pubbing and clubbing in Ireland's capital city? Then welcome to 'Black Lyn'. To get there, why not try flying with the republic's state airline, 'Lift Gates'. And if you get lost in the fair city, you can always ask an officer from the 'Hainin Polic' to show you the way back to your hotel.

No, you are not about to enter a parallel Irish universe; this is the new unionist-friendly, tri-lingual, independent Ireland. Ulster Scots - a language similar to Lallans, the native tongue of Scotland's most famous poet, Robert Burns - is set to be recognised as the republic's third official language.

Under the Good Friday Agreement, Ulster Scots, spoken mainly by northern unionists, must have parity of esteem with Gaelic. Now David Trimble's Ulster Unionist Party has wrung a major concession from the Irish government - some street signs, cross-border bodies, and even the name of the Irish parliament will be translated into Ulster Scots as well as Gaelic. In Ulster Scots, an oral language spoken by an estimated 100,000 people in Northern Ireland and east Donegal, Dublin is translated as Black Lyn, the state carrier Aer Lingus becomes Lift Gates, and the Irish police or Garda Siochana is Hainin Polic.

The man masterminding the drive for Ulster Scots' equality is John Laird, one of Trimble's allies in the House of Lords. Lord Laird of Artigarvan is co-chairman of the Irish cross-border body on languages and is determined to put Ulster Scots on a par with Gaelic.

'It is not Lord Laird, David Trimble or anyone else from the Unionist party demanding that there must be parity of esteem. It says it in the agreement and 95 per cent of the people in the Irish Republic voted for it,' said Laird. He praised the Irish Government, which he said was 'opening every door to accommodate our language in the south'.

Even Bertie Ahern, the Prime Minister or Taoiseach, will be given a third name now that Ulster Scots has been officially recognised in Dublin. Ahern will be known as the 'Haid Mannyster', while the parliament, Dail Eireann, becomes the Tolsel.

'Even though I am a unionist, I have to say the Irish government have created no difficulties for Ulster Scots. In fact, it's quite the reverse; they couldn't be more helpful to us,' Laird said.

The Ulster Scots Agency in Belfast was established following the signing of the agreement to promote interest in the language, spoken in the north since the 17th-centuryUlster Plantation.

It is also promoting Ulster Scots culture, including the first Burns Night at Buswell's Hotel, facing the Dail/Tolsel, for Irish TDs and senators in the new year. There are even plans to translate the Irish national anthem, 'The Soldier's Song', normally an offensive tune for most unionists, into Ulster Scots.

Laird singled out a number of Irish politicians for praise in helping Ulster Scots get an equal footing with Irish, especially Brian Lenihan, the son of the late Deputy Prime Minister or Tanaiste.

'During a meeting in the Tolsel/Dail last month, I spoke to Brian Lenihan about the role of Ulster Scots in American history. I told him the man who wrote the American Declaration of Independence, Charles Thompson, was an Ulster Scot who spoke our language.

'I informed him that John Dunlop, the compositor who helped print the Declaration, was another Ulster Scot speaker. But he already knew all this.'

But there is still only one political party in Northern Ireland's devolved government which bothers to translate its press releases and faxes into the northern language - Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party.
